reviewText:
These people are on crack. This is an absurdly ridiculous price for a half a season of a tv show. I borrowed it from the library and am so glad I did. Within the first five minutes of the show, you see Claire being raped. Then she's beat up by Jaime. The first episode ends with her on top of him having sex while threatening him with a knife. Naturally they are both in the throes of ecstasy.

Are you kidding me? I truly don't understand why this is so popular. I didn't watch anymore after that. I don't see anything romantic about rape and domestic violence. And there is ZERO chemistry between these two. It's dry, dry, dry. The plot is also thin. This is nothing more than a rated X bodice ripper.

I just finished watching on Netflix the first 8 episodes on two DVDs. What is volume 2?
Is it another season or the rest of season 1? I'm so confused! Can someone please explain?

Watched the first volume -just had Netflix send it to me. Don't see the point in paying this much money for any tv show. Will do the same with volume 2. I have better things to do than watch something over an over as some reviewers say they do. People are silly. Sound like 5 year olds that watch Frozen 20 times. That I understand. If I wanted to watch it again NF would send it to me in one day. And no, not that I can't afford it-just think it is outrageously priced. That is 2 different things.
I am obsessed with this show! It is absolutely the best show I've ever seen! You will not be disappointed!

I am pre-ordering mine today!  I have read the books over and over, watched the first half of Season 1 several times (and now my husband is addicted too).  The production - from acting to the beautiful setting in Scotland to costumes to props - is top notch!  I have the Season One DVDs (ordered from Amazon).  You are getting 8 hours of superb film (better than most movies and equal in length to about 5 movies) along with special features and special Blu-ray exclusives.  It comes in a beautiful box and the whole thing is much nicer than other television seasons I have been given!  Well worth the money -- and SO well worth the watch!!!

This is the best TV show in every aspect on. If you pick any part of this production to study and review you will find the absolute best workers during their absolute best work of their careers. As a reader and fan of the Outlander book series I know that I am truly blessed as a fan of this show.

If you're read the Outlander book series, first published back in the 1990s, you'll be impressed by this TV version. Like Game of Thrones and other similar adaptations, the TV series takes some liberties and makes some changes -- but for me, the essence of the books is captured in the TV version.

Some of the main characters are well played and represented, like Claire Beauchamp Randall Fraser and James "Jamie" MacKenzie Fraser. There is a lot going on in the books, and that complexity is a solid foundation for any TV series. Worth watching!

OMG! Why are these SO much money!?! I LOVE the book series, just as the next "Outlander" fan does. I began reading them when they first came out, many years ago, and have read the series over and over again. However, I will not pay these prices!

I know what you're thinking - 90 something dollars for one season of a TV show?!  Expensive yes but when I think of how many times I'm going to rewatch it's worth it.  I was so happy with the amount of extra features in Vol. 1, I'm looking forward to what Vol. 2 has in store for us.  Fans of the series will be happy with the TV adaptation.  The casting is perfect (Sam Heughan as Jamie Fraser is everything) and Vol. 2 seems to be taking enough creative licence to keep fans guessing, particularly the scenes with Laoghaire.  An historical romance set in beautiful Scotland - You won't be disappointed!

I'm watching the first half of season one preparing for the DVD release, of course already ordered at whatever cost it takes. This is a MUST OWN, like the books. Too much happening to grasp it all in one viewing and the extras are also astounding to see. So true to the book, of course since Diana Gabaldon, the book author, keep near for approval. She too loves it, seeing her life's great creation come to life.

I admitted to my obsessive behavior toward all things Outlander. YES, I'm prejudiced. I began reading the Outlander series 1 1/2 decades ago. Now I own all books in hardcover, first editions, signed by the author. This DVD series holds to the great adventure style of the books. The books are 800 to over 1000 pages each, so plenty of material to continue DVDs for decades, beyond my lifetime, unfortunately.

In Volume 2, Caitriona Balfe continues as Claire, Sam Heughan as Jamie, tobias Menzies plays Frank Randall (a richer role than the book, actually), and the rest of the cast is just as suburb. I had my own image of Jamie & Clair from the novels, and the film stars are not the same, but they are very, very good. Cinematography, writing, costuming, props, choreography, is perfection, even down to what is NOT under the kilts. Top notch, as I knew it would be. Diana Gabaldon would allow nothing less.
Yep, this is a classic story in both book and film, you can bet your broadsword on it.

Update: Amazon immediately contacted me in response to my frustrated note below and offered a full refund. I very much appreciate this quick response and resolution to my problem. I don't hate the episodes. I Outlander: Season One - Volume Two I am frustrated because I thought I was ordering a DVD. Instead I had ordered online streaming. OK. My mistake. I was given the option to "cancel" the online streaming and my cancellation was denied - either doing it within 5 minutes was too long a period after ordering. Whatever the reason, my cancellation was denied. So I decided, since it was my error that I misordered that I would try watching it online (we have a slow internet so I wasn't sure if it would work, but thought I would try). When I went to watch it (having paid for this service), all my options to watch the movie were closed. The only options I could select were to re-buy it again. Could you either please refund my money or give me the permissions I need to try to watch the episodes online. If DVD is available, that would be great!

Not sure who watches that aspect of the show for fun, but it certainly stopped being something I'd consider watching to unwind. Way too much focus on graphic details. Apparently future episodes/seasons don't get much better, so we're stopping.

The premise and story line are very interesting.  Acting is excellent.  But, unfortunately, it gets bogged down with excessive nudity, sex, physical and sexual violence, torture, blood, sadistic homosexual sodomy and rape, masturbation, and bodily functions.  One minute we are on a grand adventure and the next minute things come to a screeching halt and degenerate into much too long and explicit R and X rated scenes that do nothing to advance the plot.  Okay, we get the point.  No need to show us in excruciating detail.  A brief suggestion leaving much to the imagination and then quickly moving on with the story would have been much better.  I actually got bored waiting for the story to pick up again.  Im dropping this series and won't be watching Season Two or later Seasons.

The last half of season 1 is definitely darker and grittier than the first and is not for the faint of heart. The quality of the production value of this show continues to be outstanding from the sets, locations and costumes to the realistic music, dialogue and accents. It truly is a unique and atmospheric experience to watch such a well done and engaging program. There are difficult to watch scenes but there are also scenes filled with dark humor, edge-of-your-seat excitement and suspense and standout performances from these truly phenomenal actors. I especially loved Laura Donnelly's portrayal of Jenny, I think she is spot on for the character and she did a fantastic job. Lotte Verbeek is great as Geillis I just wish her hair was the correct color (pale blonde or white), that's my only compliant about her! I was also impressed with Duncan Lacroix as Murtagh in Volume 2, he really did an excellent job. The season finale "To Ransom a Man's Soul" is hard to watch but is necessary to the plot and I commend both Sam and Tobias on their performances. However, the aftermath of Jamie's ordeal in Wentworth plays out a little differently in the book and I'm not sure how much I like the changes the show had. For instance, in the show, I think Jamie appears to recover and act like himself a little too quickly after Claire is finally able to get through to him. *SPOILERS* He takes a lot of longer to recover and Claire really has to go to some frankly disturbing lengths to get him to realize that Randall doesn't own him... the show really doesn't compare to that scene in the book in this instance. In the book he also nearly dies from the fever which was kind of glossed over in the show. I felt like the last 30 minutes of that episode were rushed and included too many flashbacks to Jamie's ordeal with Randall... showing some of what he went through is necessary but I don't think it had to be as drawn out or explicit as those scenes are. I'm personally not at all easily offended by such graphic content or by the homosexual sex/rape scenes but I do think it was a little too much and many people will be offended or at least uncomfortable. Like I said, the content in this show is not for the faint of heart; it's gory and graphic and realistic. Once again, like I will say in all my reviews for each season of Outlander, if you haven't read the books, you really should! This was my second time watching season 1 (I watched it the first time on TV when it originally aired) and this show is great for re-watching and for binge watching.

I've watched season 2 the show is very entertaining. Personally im not a Claire fan at all. I was literally laughing my but off when they stripped her and beat her at her witch trial. Claire is one of those women that is always in everyone business cant shut up for one minute to look and think before she speaks or acts. She is in a time period where women have no voice they are basically property so you really have to think and out wit to get your point across, she's like screw all that work your going to listen to what I have to say. I really was not a fan of her when she tried to spill the beans about Lady Louise de Rohan's pregnancy. Lady Louise de Rohan had been nothing but kind to her when she arrived to Paris and talked to her when no one would for her to even think about doing what she planned was rotten. The very first day they arrived in Pairs she got them in trouble, a the lord tried to poison her. I was not  fan when she attempted to blame Jamie for the loss of their first child She was working every day at the clinic instead of resting and getting ready to have a baby and tasting people urine, I was like is this heifer crazy! I really freaked out when she was about to go in labor and left the house to look for Jaime any other woman would be like take me to the hospital I have no time for this crap.

I do enjoy the series. I appreciate period period pieces and enjoy the history. And it is a fairly engrossing tale. However, as it goes on more and more I really detest the lead character, as she really is a selfish narcissist. I try to enjoy the rest of the story and ignore how she carelessly tramples everyone else, and is elevated beyond the value of every other character, and indeed, an entire clan. She IS married to two people, she DID steal a girl's childhood sweetheart, to save herself. And the man she stole, she never even intends to stay with. She really is a terribly rotten person. So I enjoy the rest of the show and the other characters, and hope she isn't rescued for the hundredth time by the people she endangers with her stupidity and loud, foul mouth, and puts in danger with her selfish choices, and never really intends to devote any loyalty to after all. (When they didn't burn her as a witch I was very disappointed.)
If an angry, paranoid, narcissistic feminist wrote a romance novel, with a woman in a torn blouse on the front cover and her rakish lover, THIS would be that story. Every man she is cheating on, or with, is a cuckolded, emasculated idiot DEVOTED to her because she's just so awesome. And every other man is a rapist. And through the entire series, she's super important while everyone else is cannon fodder for her needs. But she's the poor, always victimized damsel...
All that said, it IS an engrossing tale. Though the author clearly had some serious personal issues.

This is not a review based on Outlander Season One - Volume Two, it is a review based on my paid subscription through Amazon with Starz - I was able to watch Outlander with my service up until yesterday and all of a sudden today it is prompting me to pay 2.99 per episode (even season 101 which was included and watched) until today (Thanksgiving of all days)... I called Amazon and they said that it wasn't them, it was Starz controlling the content and hadn't "uploaded" it yet, but that makes absolutely no sense to me considering I watched up to Season 102 - episode 2 up until yesterday and showed as free with subscription.... Please Amazon - this is misleading and it needs to be fixed!

Why doesn't Claire just take Jamie with her into the future instead of going back into the past and staying there? If I were her, I would much rather live with indoor plumbing, running water, electricity, central heating, air conditioning, etc., than in the primitive conditions of 1700s Europe. He also would not be a fugitive or be suspected of sedition or treason. I suspect Jamie, once he got used to it, would prefer it also. Having him adjust to the 20th century instead of her adjusting to the 18th century would, I think, make for just as interesting a series. It wouldn't be "Outlander", but it would seem more logical to me.

Most of the first season was amazing. That they put the time traveling in the back seat of the history and culture of the Scotts in the 18th century was a very original and fascinating thing to do, and it made for a great story. I personally think that the Frank and Johnathan Randall are the best characters in the series, probably because of just how amazing the actor's portrayal of them was, and how starkly different they are in spite of being portrayed by the same person.

So it's a great series. However, be warned: there is some level 11 horrible rape/torture in the last part of this season. I generally do not have a problem with dramatic depictions of sex, murder or rape. Horrible events are a large part of what connects an audience to dramatic characters and dramatic stories. But I think either the original author, or the writers for the show went a little crazy here. There was a little gore to the torture part, and the depiction of rape was not overly graphic in the sexual sense... but the level of depravity of the torture/rape stuff, and that they decided to drag it out so long in the telling of this story.

If you are sensitive to this sort of thing you should definitely steer clear. I am not very sensitive to this stuff at all in fiction, but how they portrayed it was pretty disturbing even for me.

I enjoyed the first season of the series thoroughly. It is like a swashbuckling romance novel. Seeing how Europeans lived during the 1700s is part of the appeal. I am a horse enthusiast, so I enjoy the riding scenes. Also the scenery and music add charm. Be advised that there is a lot of sexual scenes, semi-nudity, and violence, Not for young children.

The writers of this TV series continue to do a fairly good job of telling this story; they do it much better than the author of the books, whose writing is absolutely abysmal. Not without its flaws, but still very enjoyable. Overall, the cast is excellent, but the male lead, Sam Heughan, while looking the part, is probably the least talented actor of the entire main cast.

A faithful rendering of Diana Gabaldon's book Outlander (which I have loved since it was released in the 1990s).  Ron Moore took great care to keep to the spirit of the book and it's story line.  It is filmed in Scotland and the cast is mostly Scottish and become the inner eye's version of the roles they play (even if you pictured them differently from the book).  Cait and Sam's chemistry is through the roof and they ARE Claire and Jamie to a T.  Casting was spot on! The landscape is amazing and evocative - it too tells the story.  Terry D did miracles with the wardrobe and went a long way to transporting the viewers to the time periods in the story. The music gets into your soul and thrills you. Great care was made to ensure that it was everything it should and could be.  Every contributer outperformed - can you give an award to the entire crew, cast and country? It is : Consuming.  Haunting.  Evocative.  Captivating.  Moving.  Transporting.  Don't miss it!

If memory serves, there were scenes in the TV episodes that were missing from the DVD.)

I am an Outlander addict so I am greatly prejudiced. This series introduced me to Gabaldons main characters (I had read a Lord John book many years previously). If one has read the Big Enormous Books in her series, this covers only a small part of the first book, after  Claire's foiled escape only to  find herself again in the hands of Black Jack who intends to rape her. It is all beautifully filmed and converted me to an addict. It is however the grimmer part of that first book, ending of course with Jamie being tortured by Jack in the prison and Claire helping him escape. The Wentworth Prison scenes are extremely graphic, there is full frontal nudity, and lots of blood. There is also a twist in the story as to how Jaime ends up captured in the first place, and I felt the battle scene that replaces the original was visually accurate, and therefore distasteful. It is not something I would suggest be viewed in the presence of young children. Also first episode contains the scene where Jamie beats Claire with his belt and the makeup sex, very close to what is in the book, is very graphic and probably I wouldn't want my teenagers watching that either. Both scenes however are necessary to the later story  remaining accurate for future seasons. I love the book and the film version. I am an addict and prejuced. If one has not yet read the books though I include this waring as to viewership. You can usually find some episodes of the film on Starz, or bits of the episodes on Facebook fan groups so I would recommend exploring a bit of them before purchase if you are not familiar with the books already. As for the DVDs they do include some out takes and deleted scenes that the addict who has viewed the series on TV will appreciate.

I just recently started watching this series and my first thought was this is a woman's program.  It dragged a bit as the plot developed but my patience was rewarded by a nude scene in which Caitriona Balfe, the lead actress, who played Claire Randall gave the audience extended views of her beautiful breasts. Of course, there are many handsome men in the series to keep the women interested. I am now in the middle of Season 2 and Caitriona has bared her breasts in almost all the episodes, all instances being very tastefully done.

The series is purely fictional, but considerable effort was obviously given to some historical accuracy.  The wardrobes, speech, grooming, events of the time all appear to be what you would expect in 1743 Scotland.  Claire Randall is English and is forced to adapt as an outsider into 18th century Scotland during a period of high tension between the Scot's and occupying English forces.

Season 1, Volume 2 ends with a terrible homosexual rape/torture scene that seemed to go on for an eternity.  After the first few minutes of the scene I was thinking "enough, I get the idea", but the scene continued on and on.  I have to give the actors and all others involved credit for producing this incredible scene.  It must have been unbelievably difficult for the actors regardless of their sexual persuasion. A series of events throughout Season 1 led up to this scene.

I am almost done with Season 2 and will be lost when it is over.  Fortunately, Starz has renewed the series for a third season which is scheduled to start in early April 2017.

Very graphic.  Had to look away from movie when skin, blood, bones, intestines, and decaying bodies were on the screen.

Sam Heughan is wonderful as James "Jamie" Fraser.
Heughan and Caitriona Balfe (who plays Claire Beauchamp) have great chemistry together.
Tobias Menezes is a sadistic amoral villain as Jonathan Randall.

He is extremely patient & understanding with a woman who always thinks she knows more & better than everyone else thus creating most of the problems & obstacles in the story.  That can stretch credulity too often.

Few Scots were Roman Catholic in 1743 though some Presbyterians did convert to Roman Catholicism so it is strange that the village church is headed by a "priest" who uses a crucifix and makes the sign of the cross.  Otherwise, the story seems well-researched, but I haven't found any sources supporting Roman Catholicism in the Highlands.
Loved it, recommend it, the historical  and psychological aspects are  interesting and intriguing.

The last two episodes of this volume, the end of season one, are two of the most intense, disturbing, superbly acted episodes I have ever watched. I knew what to expect. I have read the books. But I was not expecting the level of reality of the suffering of one man and the depravity of another.  Season two of Outlander, the second half of the first book in the series, is worth watching again and again. Starz has a winner with this series, and it's been picked up for two more seasons.

Whereas the first volume showed the darker side of Scottish history and tidbits of how the Jacobite Rebellion would come to be, this volume shows the darker side to marriage too many don't like to face- particularly how far one would go to save a loved one.
From volume 2's opening to the last moment of the season finale, I was engrossed (even with the gross gay sex scene). There's not just cringeworthy violence, erotic sex scenes, etc., I mostly enjoyed the deep psychology of the show. The psychology of the most controversial episode had me thinking the hardest. How to save a man when his mind has been twisted along with his body? That angle had me impressed beyond what I expected.
This had me thinking it was like the Scottish modern interpretation of Song of Solomon- the good, the bad, the ugly of marriage.
The season is worth rewatching for all the layers, the reverse foreshadows, how well acted Tobias Menzies was as a man and his ancestor, and especially the laugh-out-loud wit of both Claire and Jamie.

Something bothered me about this season (aside from the obvious, the last 2 episodes). I went back and read the book closely. Some things were left out that really made  the book better. For example in the book after the beating episode, Clair and Jamie spent time together talking and ended up rolling on the ground laughing. None of the petulance shown in the TV movie. Second, in the movie after Clair decides to stay with Jamie she stands over him snapping "get up soldier". NOT in the book where their reunion was much more tender. Little things mean a lot. Same problem with Season Two though I am currently reading "Dragonfly in Amber" to check.

This series ended up being more like a gory porno than a love story. Clair is all too often on the verge of being raped, by captain Randal, by Dugal, and various British officers. The sex scenes are WAY OUT of bounds for family viewing. The language is terrible and story line is one continuous victimization after another. I kept holding on thinking the story would turn out ok but the last episode left me feeling sick to my stomach and dirty. The images are forever seared in my mind. The only thing I can say is that only a very sick mind would be capable of writing such a twisted story. It could have been amazing but instead I hated it. Don't we have enough violence in the world, enough murder, enough rape, must every movie be disgusting too? I am sending the second season back- the first season was garbage for the mind.

I love Outlander

More of what I wrote in my Volume One review except the heroine is beginning to migrate into unrealistic territory as a do-all, be-all as she struggles to adapt to her new life and love. The evil Brits are coming down hard on them all, the land is full of Scottish collaborators, and her squeeze, Jaime, becomes a hunted man so they have to ultimately sail off to France in the end.

As always there are some hard scenes to watch depending on your bent but the overall action and tension are pretty much carried over from Volume One. But the novelty begins to wear for me thus dropping it down a star. There's a lot of Clare/Jaime fighting followed by kiss and make-up filled in between by sword and musket play that begins to become repetitious. Taken as a whole however it's still a fine series.

Great series.  I read the books before I decided to watch the series because I found most series or movies do not follow the books.  I was pleasantly surprised with Outlander.  Even though there are subtle differences in the series than the book, they aren't things that deter from the overall end product.  The series does stay pretty true to the books but with a few variations.

I do have to mention one thing that bothers me with casting in the series.  If you are an avid Outlander reader as I am, you notice things.  Some of these things are, Claire's eye color and Jenny's eye color.  The book states a number of times the "amber color" of Claire's eyes but her eyes are brown, nothing significant, in the series.  Jenny's eyes are blue in the book, in fact, they are the bright blue like Jamie's, but they are also brown in the series.  Wouldn't you have the actresses use colored contacts to make the impact and follow the book?  Obviously not.

I know there isn't a lot to say about the series that hasn't already been said, but this series is very graphic.  The violence, situations, and sexual scenes are graphic.  This is not a series for the faint-of-heart, so if you're at all squeamish about these things, do not watch, or fast forward through the icky parts.

This is truly an epic series.  The books are larger than life and are absolutely wonderful to loose yourself in.  The characters are loveable and the dialogue is witty and engaging.  Love the books and now I'm hooked on the series.

I loved the Outlander books and the series does a very good job of following the books- a little too good, at times. I don't understand why they felt it necessary to show full frontal nudity so frequently or full-on rape scenes in graphic detail. I get that it was part of the book, but reading about it and seeing it are two different things, and I don't know why they feel it necessary to nearly make the series rated X. The storyline itself is true to the books and I love the characters, I just think they could stand to tone down some of the sexuality. You can't erase the sexuality and stay true to the books, I know that, but it doesn't have to be so overt.

After reading the first book, I realized that it has taken over my life. I'm now on book 4. I read it, listen to the audio and watch the series on Starz.

My cable was off around 2 am, (which is often the case with Xfinity), and at that time of night/morning I am usually so frustrated with not being able to sleep I forget I can watch movies on Prime. So, I decided to go through some DVD's I borrowed from my mom, in which I am most certain I purchased this for her or my grandmother from Amazon. Finding this, I figured it would be perfect enough to loll this unfortunate insomniac straight to sleep. On the contrary! I was hooked with the first episode. I didn't get any sleep that night or the next due to being glued to my television set. And wouldn't you know, the day before finding this gem I had Starz turned off the cable because I never watch it. I now have Starz from Amazon and it's $11 cheaper!
The story-line holds my undivided attention (not that I normally have all that much going on at 2am); the costumes, characters and scenery are absolutely beautiful and the acting is superb. (I never use the word superb, hmm) Highly recommend NOT to watch at 2am, unless that's your thing. Guess I will have to purchase some melatonin, because (happily),this strategy backfired.

I am with the hundreds of thousands of people around the world that are glued to the Outlander Series.  The masterful story teller, Diana Gabaldon has put forth the most riveting, account of Scottish and American history encompassing Claire, an intelligent young "modern" woman with medical acumen from the 1940's and Jamie, a handsome young, Scottish Highlander clansman from the 1740's weaving them and their family and friends through the survival of disasters and wars while developing the most sincere and tender love story between the two of them. She's managed to make a truly believable narrative of a woman who accidentally falls through time from the 1940s to the 1740's into the colonial mores and values of people of that time.  Claire struggles with how people lived two centuries ago and how she may be able to apply her knowledge of medicine and history and perhaps change the time-line to help the people she loves in the 1740's while dealing with concern about Frank, her husband, desperately searching for his missing wife during their second honeymoon in Scotland after the end of WW II.
SAM HEUGHEN IS MAGICAL AND A HALF---GREAT STORYLINE---CAN'T WAIT FOR MORE.

Anxiously waiting for next installment!  Have watched segments over and over  Didn't care for Paris episodes. Segments with Claire & Jamie are best. Talked to numerous friends & they are in total agreement.  Put next part of series on air asap. Best series on television. Lauretta Buchanan

This was one of those the wife and I would watch together one episode at a time.  While it danced along the razor's edge of tastefulness with it's explicit sex scenes, the romance, drama, action, and period setting made it tolerable...that is until season 1 volume 2's conclusion.  We kept watching, hoping we were misunderstanding the homoerotic torture fueled scene that ended volume 2 - but we didn't.  It's really quite sad, the series had so much potential...but lost it, to trying to out "gross-out" GoT.  Season 1 volume 2 manages to be exceed GoT's explicit depictions, but in doing so fell off that razor's edge with predictable consequences, and it's why we've thrown the DVD's out and won't watch another season.

Season 1 - Volume Two of Outlander is gritty, realistic, sometimes hard to watch. Cinematography, writing, costuming, is perfect...a magnificent production. A fantastic adaptation  of Diana Gabaldon's book series.  Scotland scenery is spectacular!

I'm totally enamored with the show. Wonderful heart wrenching, captivating story involving you to the point where the characters seem so real you feel a sense of loss when not seeing them. This motivated me to read Voyager,which is based on Season 3.  Also to take further interest in Scotland's history.

Beautifully written, breathtakingly filmed. Outlander transports viewers to a time and place of brutality  and passion. A mixture of romance, history, adventure, violence, sex and evil. The acting is truly the best I've ever seen. Caitriona Balfe as Claire, Sam Heughan as Jamie are superb, as are all cast members. Amazing onscreen chemistry between Claire and Jamie. Truly feel the love between them. Words of love Jaime speaks are so heartfelt they give you chills! He is a proud Scottish warrior/hero and tender lover. Claire the strongest of female characters.

The last two episodes were tough to view.  Very disturbingly realistic depiction of Jaime's torture and rape. Psychological effects were explored in depth. Jamie and Claire struggle through these two episodes, coming to terms with the aftermath of evil but it is an incredible testament to the power of love.

Questioned weather I would be able to continue watching after the last episode but pleased I did because the series is greatly rewarding and thought provoking.

I wish I could give it TEN STARS! I just discovered Outlander via NetFliX DVD. I devoured Season One - Volume One - However they could give no date for when Volume two would be available - so I decided to check out Amazon-Prime and there was a brand new email from Amazon Prime offering up a free 7-day trial for their new "best-Buddy -> STARZ"! And STARZ just happens to have Season One-Volumes 1&2 AND Season Two-Volume-One!!! I have been in Outlander Heaven for the past 2 days! The sets, the costumes, and most of all - the Actors are absolutely Beautiful! And, being man or woman, you are going to LOVE this couple! Oh, did I mention The SeX?  There is also quite a bit of Blood and Violence, but I believe they offset the horror of it very well. Just when you think you can NOT take their pain another second, you are given relief with a scene change. The only thing I fear is that it seems like every time a really awesome series comes around, the networks cancel it! (most recently - "Hell on Wheels") If you haven't watched Outlander - give it 30 minutes. You will be hOOked!

An entertaining -- albeit more serious -- continuation of Claire and Jamie's adventures in the 17th century Scottish highlands. Not all is idyllic and romantic! Women's roles are very circumscribed and Scotland is oppressed by Hanoverian England. Jamie escapes capture and hides in remote parts of the highlands while Claire searches for him only for Jamie to be recaptured and possibly executed by the evil Black Jack Randall, an ancestor of her 20th century husband!

Love this series! As is true of Diana Gabaldon's books, the characters are compelling and the plot is skillfully conceived and written. As for the TV production, the acting and costuming are great; the music is wonderful, especially the opening theme; cinematography and location shooting is excellent; I'm incredibly drawn to the history, people and culture of Scotland. But I kept hearing how great the series was.. so I had to do it..  I watched the first episode and thought 'meh'  - but then kept going through the series. It did pick up for me - I do think it is very well made - well acted.  Jamie is just adorable and Sam Heughan is well cast and he is just utterly charming.  I find Claire rather annoying but I'll put up with her to be able to watch Jamie... Great attention to detail for a period piece.  Pretty heavy on the history so if that is not your thing - you may have trouble with it.

I've noticed that i am not obsessed with watching it like I currently am with a couple of other series - I am fine to watch an episode then drop it and not watch another for a week or more.  Whereas I will watch others episode after episode till all hours of the night -  so that confirms my rating,  I like it - but I don't love it.. Except for Sam - him I give 5 stars to... ;-)

Led by Sam Heughan as Jaime Fraser and Caitriona Balfey as Claire Beauchamp Fraser, this excellent series is a faithful rendering of Diana Gabaldon's brilliant books and historical research.  Set in both modern (1945-1975) and medieval times (1745-1775) , the series offers a blend of remarkably accurate history, strangely convincing time-travel fantasy, and a lyrical sensuality of physical love.  The strong central characters are surrounded by a rich tapestry of events and supporting cast, several of whom have won awards for their dramatic work.

Watching Outlander and reading the books on which it is based, led me to understand for the first time, the context surrounding the Scots "rising" of the middle 18th century, when Bonnie Prince Charlie attempted to take back the English throne for his Catholic father. The series is unsparing in its revelations of Prince Charles' utter incompetence for the role, and of the unbridled brutality of the English Protestants in suppressing the rebellion.

Due to frequent bloody violence consistent with the period and highly erotic sexuality that molds the characters, this is decidedly adult entertainment.  That said, my wife and I eagerly await the release of Season Three in Fall 2016.

This historical romance is beautifully filmed in the Scottish highlands. It depicts a life dominated by the Scotch clans as they struggle with England, represented by the red-coated English army.
  The main character, Claire, is an English nurse, and we meet her right after WW II as she and her husband begin a new post-war life together. She has just committed herself to this new life when she finds herself thrust 200 years back in time. Her knowledge of history, her husband's genealogy, and medical arts are all important elements in the plot of this complex drama. Be prepared for plenty of raw sex and violence, 18th century style.
  I loved the story, the scenery, the 18th century costuming, the history lesson, and--being a woman-- the wonderful body of the male lead, Jamie, an 18th century Scotch warrior and Claire's lover.

I watched the first 1/2 of Season 1. This is the second half, the  continuing story of Claire (who's on the selfish
side) & slightly younger Jamie who's coming into his own. At times I wondered- did Claire deserve Jamie's
devotion?

The Red Coat officer known as "Black Jack" was rotten to the core.  His character was sadistic toward  Jamie & ultimately raped him- these scenes could have been brief, implied w/o  the gory details or left out completely. But controversy generates interest which generates TV ratings? I have not seen such a detestable character portrayal since Ronald Merrick in Jewel in the Crown on PBS.

I realize this TV experience (now on DVD)  was based on a series of time-travel romance books. But it strains credibility that Black Jack would miss the notice of his commanding officer or the jail warden while subjecting Jamie and others to his nefarious actions.

The leads had chemistry, but I think the other characters w/ their quirks & power-plays made this story come alive. And gave it texture. I don't have a huge screen TV, so only about 50% of the subtitles were visible.

Initially I checked this series out at the Library, because it looked interesting. I fell in love with it immediately! I had to own it, so I bought it from Amazon. The second season is currently under way on Starz, but I don't have cable. I can't wait to see season 2! The story is based on the books by Diana Gabaldon. Her Outlander series currently totals 8 books. I have started to read the series. Each book is over 600 pages long, so it will take a while. The TV series does an excellent job of following the characters and scenes written in the books. However, I do find the TV series more enthralling, because the characters are much more animated with their Scottish accents, which is not as clearly indicated in the books. The first season (Volume one and Volume two) only covers the first book Outlander. The story line is interesting, because it throws a married woman for 1945 into a dangerous Scotland in 1743, under British rule. She is a head-strong independent modern woman who has to come to terms with 1743 society where women were in constant peril and had little say or control over their own lives. She initially finds herself in the position of being suspected as a spy by both the Scottish clan that is keeping her, and by the British. In order to protect her from the evil hands of her 1945 husband's ancestor, the clan decides it would be best for all concerned if she married Jamie, who is a relative of the clan's leaders. She struggles with the morality of being married to two different men, from two different times, but does her best to cope with her current situation, when all she really wanted was to find a way home. Under the circumstances, she starts to fall in love with her new husband, but Scottish life continues, with its ups, downs, and political intrigues, and she continues to serve as the healer (because she is a nurse) for the clan. Because she is from the future, she also has some knowledge of events that are about to unfold that may be used to help the clan she is with, especially since she is now a member of it.Outlander: Season One - Volume One (Blu-ray + UltraViolet)Outlander: Season One - Volume Two [Blu-ray]

I recently got turned on to this show and started binge watching the back episodes.  OMG!  This show is great!  Some of the dialog is hilarious, especially from Angus and Rupert.  Other aspects are tragic.  Frankly, this show regularly has me in tears during the sad parts.  The love story of Claire and Jamie is epic.  Jack Randall is the most horrifying villain to come along in some time.  All of the actors and actresses are first rate in my opinion.  The scenery in the Scottish Highlands is glorious.  I'm so glad I found this show.  I've started reading the books now too to fill in any details that the TV show may have omitted due to constraints of time and budget.  A caveat for parents, though.  There are many aspects of this show that are very violent as life in the Highlands was violent during this time period.  I won't give away any plot points, but some things cannot be unseen once you see them.  There is also quite a bit of nudity and sex being depicted.  It all goes with the story, but this is definitely not for children.

I just read Outlander and learned of it's existence recently, so this review is late to the party. But based on that book, the few episodes I've seen from each of the seasons, and the reams of comments on the books and television episodes, I feel motivated to leave this review because there are far more outstanding ones than this series deserves. I liked it for the nostalgia factor with a nod to the bodice rippers I read in my youth. Because this is essentially an historical romance. Yes it has time travel, but it is an underdeveloped idea. I don't have a problem with the sex scenes, that is after all, the reason de atre of the whole production. The problem with them is that callow actors don't know how to do convincing sex scenes yet.  I'm not saying I didn't enjoy watching them, but I overlooked the dress rehersal feel and read into them what I wanted. Claire breathes like she's got consumption and climaxes almost as soon as Jaime touches her, for instance. I'm sure it's difficult to do sex scenes in front of a crowd and I sympathize, but I'm not the one getting paid for it. Sam H. is the better actor here, in my opinion, but at times there is still something missing. I'm not trying to blame it all on Caitriona. But I like Sam in his character better than she in hers. Even though he is not what you'd expect based on the description of Jaime in the books. Meanwhile, other characters that are acted very well are also under utilized. Though the actors do have some chemistry, you can tell the movements are contrived. Compared to say, The Lover, in which to this day people will try to claim the sex was real. I strongly believe Sam H. is gay, but that is irrelevant....because he is an actor. I was temporarily enthralled with Outlander. Love the Scottish hero, the time travel, the brotherhood of the clan and the adventure. The basic premise is really good. But the writing is mediocre. Plots elements are thrown in willy nilly,  unnecessary problems and convenient resolutions abound. I wish the producers of the show would have taken more control  and improved the story to it's potential. I wasn't sure about Sam H. for his role at first, but he grew on me quickly. In fact he's the main reason I watched as much as I did. Catriona B. is good in her role, but something about her feels insincere. It's not awful, it's just not great. I think it's partly incomplete character development. There's a lot of talk of how Claire is a strong female character. But not nearly enough mention of how annoyingly often she does stupid, selfish things that get Jamie captured and tortured. There is absolutely no attention paid to her adjustment to life in the 18th century. Speaking of violence. This author has a sick fascination with the gruesome. I have a problem with that right from the start, but then she throws it in gratuitously half the time. Like the infamous scene where Black Jack tortures and rapes Jaime. The rape could have been a strong plot point but important information like Jack's motivations are not explored and the extreme violence doesn't make sense. Even if it were important to the story, no one but an actual sadist wants to see that. Poor Jaime. At any rate, as others have pointed out, it would have been better to leave much of that to the imagination if it had to be there at all.

As for the spanking scene: I cannot believe the number of people who are outraged over this. Its ridiculous. He didn't punch her in the face for god sake, he did not beat her within an inch of her life, as I think she claimed in the book. He spanked her. People pay for that. Granted, that is a consensual transaction and granted it was with a belt. But still, haven't any of the outraged ever read a Rosemary Rogers book? (I think the author has, Outlander is basically Sweet Savage Love in Scotland except Jaime is a nicer hero. )  And if you have read SSL, please go on down to the Goodreads comments. Worth it. ) I would be more upset over the gratuitous horror show that was Jaimes torture by Black Jack in prison and the excessive, near- fatal floggings the poor guy got. And Im just speaking of the book, I couldn't bring myself to watch it depicted. Im not saying non-consensual spanking should be a regular part of a relationship, but I am saying she deserved this one and I don't feel bad for her. I liked the scene but agree with others that the music didn't quite work. I did not read any of the books and I was totally unfamiliar with the story. I saw the recommendation on Amazon Prime so I gave it a try. I became totally engrossed in the story because it was such a well designed look back to another century. It's obvious the production designers did a lot of research. The costumes and set designs were incredible and the acting top notch.
My only criticism would be that sometimes the Gaelic accents were hard to understand and I wanted subtitles. Also, there are times when I wanted the story to move a bit faster but it seemed to lag in parts. Overall and excellent production and I thoroughly enjoyed it.

Although I know the book has graphic sexual scenes, I would have preferred less so in the movie.  I also found I am not fond of the choice of actress for Claire.....she doesn't quite fit my vision of Claire in the books...neither does Jamie...he should be taller.....what a "big Scot" should look like.

Both my husband and I love this show.  The actors are great, the history is interesting, the costumes are fantastic!  And Claire and Jamie's chemistry is unparalleled in any other show I've seen.  I wish it were on every week of the year.

A gritty, taut, yet hopeful story that's not afraid to also be romantic . . . something of an antidote to the current slew of excellently-wrought, yet grim, nihilistic TV series fare.  Wonderful sets, costumes, and general evocation of period back up an excellent script and top-drawer acting.  The casting is spot-on too.  Tobias Menzies in particular deserves awards for a performance of astonishing breadth.

Outlander does slip briefly in brief moments of cheesiness - but only here and there, and invariably makes up for it within a few scenes.  Also, the distaff perspective is refreshing and still not portrayed often enough in the current TV series renaissance.  Those who like girls will have no argument with Caitriona Balfa, and Sam Heughan is her worthy counterpart.

Overall, good-to-excellent and highly recommended.

Ahh, the fabulous show known to me as "tits-out-lander". Actually my wife purchased this. I was working away on an edit and came downstairs to grab a drink, and there on the TV was a fabulously elegant and beautiful Irish lady, with her apparel all amiss astride some male-model type. For weeks after that, it seemed I had some strange mental radar - I'd have a sudden urge to get an iced tea, a scotch, some cheetos, and when I passed my lovely wife watching TV, there was - again!!! - that same pair of white Irish bosoms on screen. I asked her if this show was just straight-out softcore porn, but no - she said "your timing is just really good".

I am now developing a phone app. Anytime your wife is mooning over the romance of time travel - the emotional intensity of loving not one but TWO good men (and one of them is IN ANOTHER ERA OF TIME!!!) - the fantastical sight of brawny, handsome lads in kilts... the deep declarations of manly love to their well-bosomed Irish lasses - an alert will sound when Caitriona's corset hits the floor. I can't rely on this radar forever after all.

UPDATE: guys, avoid the, umm "prison scene". Apparently, prisons have been about the same for millennia, especially for pretty male-model-types. Owie. Thank god I was warned!

I have been binge-watching season one of the show and I have to say I am quite disappointed. My experiences with the books has been excellent; I bought the first books when they came out way, way back when and eagerly awaited each new book. So, when the show was announced, I yelled yippy!

I should have kept my yips to myself.

For instance, the show episodes are only "loosely" based on the books. So, so many things are different, or even just plain wrong. I won't go into any great detail because fans of the books and fans of the shows will know what I mean. I understand screenwriters have to make concessions because they cannot do exactly as the books are written. I know they have material and/or physical constraints. However, at least two-thirds of the books are cannibalize for the sake of the Starz shows.

But one glaring difference was the wedding. I was extremely disappointed to see that Frank and Claire were married at the local City Hall, and not at the quaint ancient church as stated in the book. I wanted to see her reaction when she went to the same place with Jamie. Another difference was I also wanted the courtroom scene to be faithful to the book. None of it was true. It would have been wonderful to see Jaime ride up on his horse and throw the jet-bead rosary on her to land just-so.

As I stated, too many differences. If you watched the shows without having read the books, they would stand alone and be fine---IF you do not mind watching nudity on a grand scale almost every time Jamie and Claire kissed or touched each other. Not my cup of tea. I fast forwarded. They should have been rated R, not MA.

Ms. Gabaldon, you have been a comfort to me on many sleepless nights while I read your books. And read them so often I had to buy them again and again, until the Kindle came along. I will continue to buy your books. However, I do wish the shows had remained true to the stories you tell about a lovely girl and her fairy tale prince come to life.

I enjoyed the books so much, I've read them three times. I was hoping the video series would be just as good, and  it is in many ways - great choice of actors to portray characters, does a good job of representing the story line without too many changes, and the changes made do not change the story in any way. My complaint, and why I can give this only 3 stars, I am not a voyeur.  I do not enjoy watching other people engage in sex, I think the "illusion" is much more romantic and effective. Blatant nudity and sex  is more on the lines of the Playboy channel and does not do the book any credit. Yes, the book has sex in it, but reading about it (which I also don't do a lot of) and seeing it our two different things.  So all that being said - The video stays true to the story, I think most Outlander fans will enjoy it ... voyeurs definitely will.  I just have to fast forward through all those scenes to get back to the story.

Warning - while this is for the most part has been a brilliantly written and beautifully filmed TV series the Wentworth Prison episode has the most nauseatingly, graphically violent and depraved scenes imaginable - seriously makes the worst scenes of Breaking Bad or the Sopranos look like kids movies. We're really torn on whether to continue to season 2, too bad because we really loved the show up until it became a torture training film.

If I had never read the books, I probably would have liked it more, the costumes are beautiful and the story is compelling. However, it is not true to the novels and that really bummed me out.  Jamie Fraser is supposed to be a giant, towering over everyone around him but in the show, he's almost the same height as Claire. I absolutely loved all 8 or 9 volumes of this series -  both as a read and as audible.  If find the story inventive, riveting, full of surprises and subplot sprouting.  A vast cast of characters, most of whom are sufficiently defined so that we can relate to them.  I do' usually like historic fiction, or sic fi, but this series made a convert of me.  The writer is knowledgeable in many fields,  English and Scottish history,  the early days of the American colonies and the war of Independence,  herbology,  medicine,  etc etc.  The characters are real people, grown ups, who address human and ethical problems in an in depth fashion.  The stories are written in a vivid, colorful fashion, the French Court is brought to life as well as a Southern Slave plantation, as well as practically endless scenarios through which the action rolls.  Not to forget the centerpiece of the whole story, an incredible, passionate, enduring love affair and the creation of a life long partnership among equals.
I love the spoken version, the reader's accents, inflections and dramatic enactment of the many plots of this world I like to visit even after I finished reading it through at least twice.

The superior video production of the Outlander saga is continued in this DVD which covers the second slice of the story based on Book 1 of the novels.  There are currently 8 remarkable novels of the mainstream story in print, so this video series may have very strong opportunities for some time to come. What makes Outlander video production so unique is the manner in which the story, which originated in large novels, has been written for the screen with great fidelity (to the books) and maybe a little degree of reverence for those remarkable works of historical fiction.  Of course the video story is compressed to fit into a reasonable of episodes by that masterful screen writing.

The DVD is delightful to watch, beautifully photographed, and wonderfully acted.  Casting is being done by wizards I think.

Hmmm.. Season 102 is a far cry from Season 101. I always hate when characters do completely unbelievable things; or they do things that are either so good or evil that their actions put them outside human capability; or they do things that are so stupid that you end up shouting at the television and smacking your head. It's so distracting. I don't know if these events are original flaws from the author of the books or are creations from the screen writers, so I don't know whom to blame. Examples: in the first episode of Season 102, after Jamie rescues Claire from Black Jack Randall, why didn't he kill the scum right there and then? Any normal person would have done so. Up to this point, everyone can see that Black Jack is no common thug- he is truly and monstrously evil- he is insanely and obsessively evil and will not stop until he has ruined the couple. So... why leave him there on the floor? Another example: why didn't they make sure Black Jack was dead after they rescued Jamie from the prison after the cattle ran over him? Why would you 'assume' the guy was dead? After such a horror, it's just unbelievable that they wouldn't kill him. Another example: The silliness of dressing up like a man and singing the silly tune. Let's face it. The best plan would have been togo home. If Jamie wanted to find Claire, he would have gone home to find her- no need for the complexity of their scheme. I spent the whole episode flabbergasted! And now, to agree with most people, I must comment on the male rape scene. Look, as a survivor of rape myself, I am all for exposing the seriousness of the crime, but these scenes were gratuitous. They were more about twisted voyeurism than seeking to understand. They were more graphic and sick than needed to be. No rape is like what happened in these scenes. This wasn't just rape. This was monstrous torture and a full emotional and psychological teardown of a human being that took place where physical rape was only one of many tools used to achieve a complete breakdown of Jamie's character, spirit and even his sense of self. Again, I'm not sure if the books intended to create such a Super Villain as Randall as the series does, but in my opinion, it distracts from the show. It's almost as if the writers are short of good story telling and are using sheer horror to 'entertain' instead. A note for the 'TV-MA' rating. Let's face it, folks: it is worse than the movie's 'X' rated has ever been. It is a free for all S & M Porn designation. You can't have your kids anywhere near you when you watch any series with this designation. That's too bad, in my opinion, because these types of shows would be far better with a PG-13 or even an R rating.  TV MA has become almost a free for all soft porn rating.  The best scene:  when Jamie tells Claire about his fears and terrors and Claire fights her way back to him after the rape.  I was in tears the whole time.

I am in love with this series. I admire the strength of Claire and Jamie is the ultimate man. This is really a chick series as it moves rather slow. My husband falls asleep when I watch it, but that's his problem, not mine! I can't binge this show more than 2 episodes as there is a lot to take in and it stays with me long after viewing. I fall asleep dreaming Outlander!

My fellow low-raters around here seem to be offended exclusively by graphic sex/rape scenes in the last 2 episodes. This view is valid, but primitive. The two stars were slowly developing a very deep story, and future, with sometimes brilliant acting, palpable screen chemistry and connection to the story they were hired to tell. The exterior scenes and period interiors are at times wonderful, always believable.

In these last episodes the writers put poor Claire on "stage" as an itinerant performer attempting to lure, or send a signal, via word-of-mouth, to her husband, putatively hiding out rom the English, somewhere in the surrounding countryside .In an effort to unearth some drama, some suspense, and generate contrived "karma", the writers succumbed to using--inserting into the script-- "deus ex machina", a crude and soulless device used to "fix" an uncooperative plot of which the writers lost creative control. God is pulling the strings, and what does that make the characters? Yah, puppets. But I like the series enuf to forgive any amateurish mistakes.

Some say a story is only as good as its villain. I kind of agree. And Randall is an excellent villain, behaving, however despicably, within certain believable bounds, committing believable atrocities (if that is possible)--until the last episode, until the writers, seeking to repair the faltering plot, attempt to explain what is not believable in their plot by dumping their troubles in Randall's lap, as it were. It's Randall's job now, or rather, the job of his perversions and evil proclivities--the source of his "motivation"-- to drive the plot forward (and into future seasons). Randall then, despite Tobias Menzie's great acting, becomes the emissary for weak writing of deus ex machina. The best writing is usually "character-driven" writing, when every action and event, emanates from the various characters "souls", and seems inevitable, unquestionable. and, thus satisfying. Here, in these last episodes, as I mentioned, these great actors/characters, have been turned into puppets to fulfill the writers' gerry-rigged agendas. Still, having sayed all that ... I like it.

If you're into the total emasculation of your favorite strong male character and pedophilia, stay tuned....otherwise quit at Season 102, episode 7 and imagine your own ending.

Although this book series has been around for 20 plus years, I never read any of the books until last year. I loved the books and now really love the series. It's rare that a book transitions well to a film/television show, but the cast of "Outlander" are such amazing actors that they breathe life into the books. So much so that when you read them, you only picture the actors who play them (at least for me). The first part of Season One was the foundation and establishing of who's who. The highlight being the "Wedding" episode and they lived happily ever after...hum, but they have an enemy who's name is Black Jack Randall. That being said;  the second half of Season One is far darker. It culminates in the episodes "Wentworth Prison" and "To Ransom a Man's Soul". They are shockingly raw and violent but also incredibly poignant. The love between Claire and Jamie Fraser is strong and rare. We see them off to a new adventure trying to stop Bonnie Prince Charlie in France so that the Battle of Culloden won't happen. These DVDs are a must for any fan of the books. Great drama.

I wish I hadn't read the book before seeing this series.  Despite the time travel element, the book was more historical romantic fiction and a surprisingly good example given the author's claim it was only a trial attempt.  The history was reasonably accurate and the romance was very involving.  The TV show has to condense a lot of the book and has unfortunately lost much of the depth and simplified much of the conflict in an attempt to clarify the narrative.  The character of Jamie was a little bland but he grew with the final episodes.  Claire is a bit too headstrong and shrewish compared to how she came across on the page.  The acting in general is very good.

The producers of this film adaptation have captured the soul of Dianna's book superbly.  The harshness and perverse cruelty of the period was difficult to read and witnessing it in vivid color was by no means easier; however, it underscores the message of the story:  that of the uncompromising love between Jamie and Claire.  There is biblical truth in their relationship where marriage asks the participants to commit to each other, body & soul, to protect and defend each other at the expense of one's own life.  Short of mentioning the entire cast by name I would add that the  complement of actors was well chosen.  From the two protagonists and the clans to the English redcoats, all inhabited their roles as if they were born to play them.  Each portrayal is honest and compelling.  I can't imagine the overall expense to bring these pages to life but I can only say, as a huge fan of the Outlander series, that it was well worth it.  Magnificent !  Well done, all !  Thank you!

I am not familiar with the Outlander books, but saw so many promotional pieces and interviews, and read so many positive reviews that I was very interested to see it.  I watched the first 2 episodes then many weeks later 2 more, and binge watched 6 on and off in one day.  The filming and location were beautiful, almost dreamlike.  The music mesmerizing and the costumes extremely detailed and intricate.  Definitely, a carefully thought out production to the minutest detail.  The actors peformed exceptionally in the dramatic scenes, conveying the strongest emotions and excitement.  But even with all these attributes, I cannot justify watching it, and will not go any further in the series.  Art is intertwined in life, but there are boundaries when it no longer resembles art, but becomes dark and gratuitous.  When writers and directors graphically depict the most heinous crimes and sexual details, proclaiming it necessary for the story, they are really feeding their desires to be outrageous and contretemps.  They have tremendous talent, but reduce it to rubbish, using profanity, vulgarity, and torture in their scripts, painstakingly convincing themselves that it is art.  I am sorry for them, for the actors, and for the fans who have bought into this deception.  The professed success of a book or tv series, measured by the writers, producers, directors, actors, and fans involved is a biased opinion.  The Outlander tv series had all the elements to be amazing, but added in so much disturbing, irreverent, graphic material, it destroyed itself.  There is more than enough violence and sexual dysfunction in the world, now and throughout history.  Presenting it as artistic form does not change the reality of what it is.  It always must be rejected in reality and fiction, and overcome with virtue and industry, in real life and art.

My daughter begged me to watch this. I did it as a favor at first. Now, I am floored by it. Truly.  It includes amazing scenery and in-depth characters, but the truly remarkable part of this show, based on the book series, is the way that  it looks at power dynamics between a man and a woman who love each other fiercely, almost violently, but who love their independent identities just as much.  Diana Gabaldon has created the perfect man.  The sexuality is so raw and intimate that I can truly say I have never seen such tenderness and honesty on screen.  The costumes are authentic, the music superb. This is fine art and will keep you thinking and watching way beyond your first viewing.

Outlander is based on the premise of love through the ages, but thrives on characters whose lives delve into the principles of power, honor, integrity, and loyalty. Outlander presents the perversions of political upheaval and the realities of oppression and impending war as the bones on which human character can be built. The time travel aspect brings enough of occult mysticism and romantic imaging to bolster the enduring aspect of love, regardless of setting. Thoroughly engaging and obsessively powerful series.

This adaptation is nothing short of breathtaking and magical. It is said that the mark of excellence in acting is the performer's gift of reaching into the emotional body of your audience and compelling whatever emotional response residing there to spill over into the awareness of the viewer, leaving an impression that isn't easily put away or ignored. Every actor playing each major character accomplishes this repeatedly. Extra Kudos to Tobias Menzies for his brilliant versatility in playing dual roles of Frank Randall and Captain Black Jack Randall. Always a special challenge and well played sir!!  If you have not read Diana Gabaldon's Outlander series you will still enjoy this remarkable Television series. Having read the books, I am impressed with the respect Mr. Moore and his team of cast and crew displayed in every detail of this production. To top it off the level of historical accuracy is impressive as well. If you have not read the books, you are depriving yourself of a rare treat! Some people are intimidated by their volume. I have them on my Kindle so they are easy to read. My only question, which I can't seem to get a straight answer for, is this: When I order this DVD from Amazon how do I know if I am getting the format that I can view here in the states? I have read complaints from folks who have anxiously awaited the arrival of their Outlander DVD only to discover it was in PAL format and therefore not compatible with their device. Anyone have ideas?

This series is brilliant.  It's kept us riveted, wanting to see more as the story unfolds.  It has quite a lot of nudity and sex in it, so is not for the younger viewer. Although I'm not usually crazy about sex scenes, as so often they're just put into the movie to attract viewers. However, in this series they've been cleverly included into the whole story, making the characters and their relationships believable.
There's also some brutality, which I find hard to watch, but I just look away and my husband mutes the TV while those are on :). Again, they're not just there for effect - they're part of the story.  At the same time, I'm learning more about English and Scottish history. This is a good one. Watch Volume one first, though...

This video follows the book of the same name and accidental time-traveling Claire, who fell through a circle of stones during All Hallows Eve and into 17th Century Scotland, and into the dispute between the ruling English and the lan-owning Scottish clans. Both worry that she is spying for the other, but the clans want to keep her for her benefit as a healer (she is a nurse) and the English want to torture the truth out of her. In order to keep the from delivering her to the English, she must become a Scott by marrying one. Though against marrying, she agrees this is the best course of action, and she marries Jamie Frazier, whom she likes, but comes to love. Capt. John Randall, aka Black Jack Randall for his evil black heart and tortuorous behavior, is the English soldier after Claire, and, it seems, also after Jaime. He has charged Jaime for murder which he himself had committed. Jaime had previously been jailed and Randall had whipped him with 200 lashes, leaving horrendous scars on his back. Randall is obsessed with Jaime, having a hidden sexual desire for him.

The book continues with evading capture, getting caught, and escaping -- that would be both Claire and Jaime in turn. There is lots of sexual scenes -- both good and bad. There is lots of adventure as they carr y out escape plans.

It is a long book.  Two seasons did not get through the book. I am not sure three will. Maybe four. It doesn't matter, though, because you will enjoy it. There are enough books for this to go on for a long while.

You don't get to see that book-to-screen translation come off quite so well, very often!  I also feel the casting of the characters in the books, whom I had grown to love (or hate, as the case may be), is another success.  The Scottish accents are excellent, and may prove to be difficult to follow, by some, or "easy to fall into" by others.  I'm on my second "viewing" of the series, while I await the release of the next season (or volume?).  Thank you!

I never write reviews ever. I think if you are going out of your way to write something you only have something negative to say. But my god this is the most positive review ever. I LOVE this show. I read a million good and bad reviews. Debating this show a million ways because I read reviews. Well here goes mine:

I know nothing of Scottish history nor do I know that much of early English history. But however I was able to follow very well the issue at hand. I actually found myself wanting to know more about the full history.

The chemistry between Jamie and Claire is equal to Jack and Kate from Lost or Bill and Sookie from True Blood. It's passionate and pulls you into their lives. The dynamic between the two makes you keep watching. The sex scenes are well done and amazing. But the pure pull between the two makes you continue the show. It's almost a ying and yang that continue to push each to make themselves better. It has made want to read the books immediately.

Please give this one a try. It's an adventure the whole way through. It's a romantic Game of Thrones but, dare I say , better.

This is a story that is very insighful into the Scottish culture as well as the Druids
influence in Scotland, Wales, Ireland, England and France.  It was very realistic
in terms of the base attitudes of the local villagers as well as the vulgar but
realistic soldiers that were clan warriors and fighters. The stubborn yet righteous
attitudes that enabled victory and the role that women played in terms of blame
for just being women. Women wrongly accused, childbirth without help, dungeons
filth and standing for a noble cause. In the end it is a story of romance that love
conquers all and helps one survive the impossible.

I wanted to see what all the buzz was about, so I did the Starz trial.  I wasn't thrilled with the language and porn, but I kept watching volume one because it was addicting.  I bought the DVD for volume two and planned to resell it when I was finished.  Got to the last episode and tried to skip forward as much as possible because of the disturbing scenes -and violence doesn't bother me too much. Just when you think it was safe, they keep repeating the disturbing male to male rape scene.  Volume one, male to female rape scene was mild compared to this.  It was like the director visually kept pushing your face in a pile s*** and when you come up for air, he pushes your face back down in it-over and over again.
What troubles me is that this doesn't seem to bother most people who review this-since it got mostly five stars. I guess people don't mind having their face pushed in a pile of s***-they don't think it stinks-it's art after all.  Directors keep pushing the envelope to get shock value-I think we have come to the point where nothing shocks us anymore- just entertains.  I threw my DVD in the trash.

Men could learn a lot about being a sensitive, thoughtful partner.  Women could learn just how much they influence the pace of the sexual relationship.  I am a HUGE fan.  Can't wait for Season Two!

The first season was beautiful.  The sinister and gruesome was gently woven and softened if you will by the absolute majesty of Scotland, the gorgeous clothing and of course the physical attractiveness of the characters.  We couldn't wait for season 2.  A friend of ours pirated it and offered it to us but we said no, we will wait and pay full price.  Popcorn in hand we dove into the second season and with each episode became more disappointed with the story line.  The final 2 successfully finished me off.  I understand that terrible and disgusting things happen but there is value in leaving something to the imagination.  I feel like I had a front row seat to the perverted stealing of a man's very soul which is far more disturbing than a lashing on the back, no matter how thorough.  "Sing me a song of a lass that is gone, could this lass be I?"  Indeed it is!  This bonnie lass will not recommend this series again nor purchase any other that are released.

This is one of the best series on Starz and TV.  The story is a wonderful tale anyway and the books have been best sellers for several decades.  It is about time a creative director, producers, crew and cast tackled this story.  The locations and costuming are stunning, but what makes this work is the absolute believability of the actors.  Starz has assembled committed, innovative people and it shows in the superiority of the craftsmanship. It is the finest/fiercest acting I have experienced in many a year and that is saying something considering the excellence of many contemporary performers and crews.  The relationships are seemingly so real that I have felt like I need to tiptoe out of the room and give them their privacy.  I was very sorry the Emmy's did not acknowledge awarding winning brave performances and directors.  Bravo Starz.

I have been a fan of the Outlander book series for years so when the story was put to video I was thrilled but a little concerned. It is rare that the video story can be as good as the book but in the case of Outlander I have been thoroughly satisfied. The director has followed the story line accurately and beautifully. The acting is superb the cinematography is spectacular and of course the story is fabulous. It provides an historically accurate picture of a very tumultuous time in Scottish history with a little fantasy time travel injected although it is so well done you begin to believe it might actually be possible!  Don't miss it!

It was such a wonderful storyline and SUDDENLY, spanning the better part of two episodes, we're treated to a FULL hour and a half of senseless human torture....male/male rape, bondage, branding irons, beatings, smashing limbs with hammers, nailing a hand to a table, and all this gratuitous and graphic cruelty..... went on and on and on and on and on.  Good grief, where did the plot go?  I finally bailed out and hit EJECT.  It was as if the screenwriters completely ran out of ideas on how to squeeze out two more episodes and round out the season.  Having read the books and knowing first hand the wealth of plots and wonderful stories, it really rams home the pointlessness of this pathetic "filler" by these hack screen "re-writers".  Count me out of any further purchases or viewings if this is the direction it's headed.  Have they absolutely no sense of shame in their entire bodies?

(SPOILERS). To the producers of this show:  what is wrong with you people?  The time travel bit attracted me to the story, and in the 16 episodes we watched, it is barely an afterthought.  You spend hours showing off the monster character (Black Jack) you created, and let him wreak havoc on everyone, then all of a sudden he appears to be die in one second, with no real justice dealt.  Gee, what a shame he wasn't allowed to triumph to the end.  Someone obviously thought he was such an important character.  I don't spend time with garbage, and that's what that character was.
All this talent, money and time - an absolute waste!  You people are sick!

Episode 7, Wentworth Prison, should have an NC-17 rating. I have studied violence as a profession for 25 years, witnessed a great deal of it, and many more photographs of it. This was too much for me. The way the audio lingered on the sounds of the throttling of the hanged men, the way the camera lingered on Fraser's torture and wounds, the way the script stretched the torture scenes with Randall, are all completely unacceptable for viewing by anyone under 17. And pretty much anyone. I now understand why French ladies of the evening call flogging le vice Anglais. The erotification of torture in the episode is well beyond the bounds of either.

If you could cut out the story of the people from the future going back in time to the past of the Highlanders vs English then it might actually be an awesome story. At first I was upset that they had any bit of a story of the husband missing his wife because it is impossible in the timeline for him to expend any time missing her if she returns. However I suspended science and continued on with the story. Then I noticed terms which kept being used and words which Highlanders of the period would never know or understand but yet the time traveler would use them and the Highlanders would instantly understand the meaning. Yes, there were some moments where they were confused but other times it seemed to slip past. I originally said that she must be a carrier of some sickness but then my wife argued it is possible she carries no disease so I conceded this point. So with that being said, while a very interesting story I must dismiss it. I have wasted too much time hoping that it would turn out for the better. However I will say I did enjoy the politics of the period and the Highlander life has always interested me. 1/5 because it is filled with flaws galore.
