This series is a historical fiction story that covers almost every film-making genre there is, including epic history (of 18th century Scotland),  the military occupation and fighting between the Scots and the English,  romance (which shows lovemaking from a woman's view),  fantasy and adventure (Claire's time travel),  horror (the last 2 episodes depict a sadistic rape and torture in a prison), and there is even a little comedy duo (Angus and Rupert).  It was beautifully filmed in Scotland and the music, costumes, castles, kilts, and weaponry give it a realistic feel.  The actors at times speak in the authentic Gaelic language (Ye ken? means "You know?"), and with a strong Scottish burr when they speak in English so be prepared to not understand a lot of what they are saying.  Unless you're from Scotland, of course.  Most of the story is told from Claire's 1945 English point-of-view.  Some of the episodes have very explicit nudity and violence, so be forewarned if you're sensitive to that sort of thing - this is not a show for children.  I felt that the sex scenes were tastefully done, but last 2 episodes (15 and 16) were a bit overly gruesome.  The showrunners seemed to be trying to show real life in the 1700s, but some things could have been left to the imagination.  Overall however, I really enjoyed this first season and look forward to Season 2 coming out in 2016.

We often think that the screen version of a book cannot be as nuanced and detailed as the written version. The screen versions of both Outlander Volume One or Volume Two add a lot..  The changes to make the first book of the "Outlander" historic series  more visual for the screen make Diana Gabaldon's excellent content and dialogue even more vibrant.  I'll lay out some of the vibrancy while trying not to make the descriptions spoilers for those who have not see the DVD's.

In Volume Two's episode the "Reckoning," Jamie Fraser uses a dirk to swear allegiance to Claire with some of the words used in the DVD Volume One's " The Gathering" when most of the MacKenzie clan swear allegiance to Colum MacKenzie.  In the screen version the use of a dirk by both Jamie and Claire is riveting while also much being more powerful and more sexual.  In the book version it's more incidental and symbolic though with a similar intent.  Quite wonderful that the author is a constant consultant to the screen version.  The additional explanations from the director are part of these very well done DVD's.  The additional director interviews are not to be missed.

In Volume Two's episode "The Search, "  Claire and Murtagh want to let Jamie know that they're looking for him so he contacts them.  The screen version uses a famous Andrews Sisters tune of World War II where she had served as a combat nurse. Again much more powerful than the search in the novel with other appropriate changes.

Having read and reread the book, the screen version is in some ways can be even more spell binding. Lest I ignore the tumultuous ending episode "To Save a Man's Soul," it tends to portray Claire's use of witchcraft in a more cursory manner on screen than the historical novel.  The last witchcraft trial was of a Scottish medium in 1944 so still recent for Claire.

Have not found anything anachronistic in the novel.  It's an accurate view of the era and the locations.  Just fascinating to check with the "Outlandish Companion" to check the characters, the place names and the Gaelic expressions.  The books and the DVD's all support each other!

Some folks will object to a rather dark episode that includes the rape of a male. In all seriousness -- if rape freaks you out, don't go anywhere NEAR the book or the show. I loved Season One, Vol One and give it 5 stars, however, Vol Two was disappointing for two reasons.  The "just in the nick of time" and "down to the wire" twists and unrealistic rescues are a turn-off for me. In real life Jamie would have been hanged. No way Claire would have found the keys to get into the dungeon in the short period of time that she had access to that chamber without being found out  I could go on-and-on. Two of the episodes were just a bit over-the-top. I also feel the sex scenes are unnecessarily explicit. It's very easy to get the point of what's going on without it going on-and-on. It is so graphic I find it to be just short of pornographic. I watched Vol. One twice; that will not be the case with Vol. Two.

This review of "Outlander" combines both volumes I and II.

The richness of story, pace and character development amid the inspiring Scottish landscape in this series is outstanding: the sense of time, conflict and place captivating.  I love the strength of Claire Randall/Fraser, her independent spirit, medicinal skill and her intuitiveness in surviving the extraordinary journey she is thrust into.  The brave, sympathetic and loyal Jamie Fraser is equally intuitive, and this trait seems to draw both characters together at the onset.  In fact, there is a lot of intuitiveness in this series, from both the director's end and in overall character portrayal, which I think gives a genuine feel of historical setting when one's absolute survival depended on the sharpness of one's wits.  I'm not a die-hard romantic fiction fan, but I've come to adore the growing devotion between the two main characters, Claire and Jamie.  It's almost difficult to recall the quietly brilliant Frank Randall wondering what could have possibly happened to his missing wife in the midst of her and Jamie's deepening love for one another in another era of time.

While the story, itself, holds some repetitiveness in the peril and rescue theme, it may just be a reflection of existence, which is a continuum of friction and survival, interspersed with moments of peace of mind and some joy.  It's easy to forget how raw life actually is (and certainly was, historically) when not cushioned by technological distractions and modern sensibilities.  I thought the whole "burn the witch" trial was a bit over the top, even for the residuals of a superstitious Scotland at the time.  Geillis was an interesting character who apparently turned from being a bit spooky to unsavory, yet I'm not convinced that burning both her and her baby alive at the stake was a necessary component to Claire's compelling choice at the stones.  I've ordered the whole set of Gabaldon's "Outlander" series, and so perhaps in the written story there is a deeper response in Claire to the savagery of Geillis's end that was notably absent in the filmed adaptation.

The profound intensity of the final two episodes in this series season (vol. 2) is testament to some skilled and courageous acting.  Yes, the visual content is strong, disturbing in its ability to raise emotion, both in terrifying sympathy for the brutalized victim as it is pure loathing for the sadistic victimizer, but it is more than either of these. It is further testimony to the remarkable competence and intuitiveness of Claire's character as she fights to bring her 18th century husband back from the dark, internal despair of shame and degradation.  I think it is important to note that this series is interspersed with some heavy violence from the minute Claire finds herself in another century, so viewer beware. Film and literature may be the last bastion of expressing things not wished to be stared at long...like death and the sun, as has been said, somewhere.

This is a very mystical and magical series filled with scenes of the beautiful English/Scottish countryside and castles.  It makes me want to check out those castles and historic landmarks first hand!  There's a bit of magic thrown in with the life of a young nurse who's thrown back quite a few centuries in time and has to deal with the primitive lifestyle of that time period.

It is a historical fiction series centered around events that occurred in the lives of the Scottish Highlanders and their constant and bloody struggles with the King of England and the British soldiers. Of course it's also filled with loads of romantic and sometimes quite raunchy love scenes between the British nurse, Claire, and the ever present hero and brawny Scotsman, Jamey.  It's definately not a movie for the family or the "faint of heart" with all the X-rated love scenes and bloody battles.

My husband and I enjoyed the first part of Season One, so we purchased Volume Two, hoping that it would continue with an interesting storyline, with the main characters having interesting adventures between their two worlds.

What we didn't expect was how this ended.  It was so disgusting, so graphic, SO inappropriate for what was supposed to be a love story, a bit of fantasy of time travel, not endless details of male rape and torture between Jamie and Randall.  How does any of this fit into the original story? Even if the writers and producers felt that the audience needed to be convinced that Randall was a sadistic bastard, they could have easily made that point in a lot less time.  This whole flashback to the crime of rape was dragged out unnecessarily, and that, in itself, is a crime.

This series is a must-see for romantics and history buffs alike. While the story an its main stars are cast in a time-traveling love story for the ages, it's not a "chick-flick." There is plenty for both men and women to enjoy. With the beautiful Scottish Highlands as a backdrop, it brings to life a time in history (18th century) where tensions between the Scots and Brits were reaching a fever pitch leading to the second Jacobite uprising. The series stays true to the popular book series by Diana Gabaldon. I hadn't heard of the books before I started watching the TV series, but the show so enchanted me, I've now read every morsel of her eight books. Ron Moore of "Battlestar Galactica" fame produces the series and has proven a skilled story-teller. The casting is outstanding. The main Highlander character, Jamie, is a heart-throb (seriously!), but Sam Heughan (the actor who plays the role) also is an excellent actor deserving of top awards. Catriona Balfe as Claire embodies the role beautifully. It is her story of accidental time-travel that is the main story line. A warning for some - the series is graphic in places and shows open sex scenes. While it's largely a drama, there is plenty of humor to make it an enjoyable ride. One final note, I strongly recommend the blue-ray DVD as the extra scenes and special features are well worth it.

What can I say... I fell in love with this series when I came across a free viewing for season one, volume one, episode one. Love with the story line, actors, scenery, customs, music, etc! Loved it all! Don't like the graphic whipping scenes, but they were kept at a minimum and the sex was in line with a first night as a husband and wife. Finally a story that's not all sex and violence! I immediatly ordered Volume Two when it was available. Upon viewing the first half the story was clearly adding more violence and more sex then the first volume. I had the fast forward on stand by. The last two episodes in this volume are sickening to watch. The actors acted great for what was being portrayed, but I don't find torture and rape entertaining. It goes on and on. There are some great scenes that would have easily conveyed what happen to this young man without every detail being showed. I did hit the fast forward because it was never ending. Starz went too far! I can't control or choose what comes out of the Hollywood, but I can choose what I view as a consumer. When torture and rape is considered entertainment then it's not about those who produced it, but about me who's choosing to view it. I won't be back for Season Two.

For those who haven't read the book: the story is good and the acting is excellent. I could definitely do without all the sex, torture and violence although the acting in those parts were amazing - especially the acting skills of Sam Heughan, Catriona Balfe and Tobias Menzies. I cried in many scenes, I fast-forwarded on the hard to watch parts - I don't want those images in my head. There were some good character relationship build ups - between Claire and Gellis and between Claire and Murtaugh. I would have liked to see more character development between Claire and Jamie - what I enjoyed about the volume 1 set.

For those who love the books: I would give this volume between 2-3 stars. The reason is that there were so many tender and sweet moments in the book that was not shown in the movies that were essential to understanding the characters. NO, movie adaptations are never as good as the book but I really wished:
1. After the spanking scene, their were so many sweet moments when Jamie talked about his past and the fact that he always got belted for his behavior. I thought these were so essential to understanding the two main characters and to developing their new love for each other after their hasty marriage.
2. The Lallybroch episode was all wrong! Jamie was completely out of character is this episode. In the book, he comes home and becomes Laird without being a jerk, as shown in the episode. Claire learns the way of the family and starts to fit in by visiting the tenants and using her healing skills as well as developing a warm relationship with Jenny and her family. This was not developed in the episode. The book allows even more growth between Claire and Jamie - it makes us realize that they are growing more comfortable with each other and that they can live their lives as man and wife. I also disliked that Jamie had no pants on in the stone mill scene. In the book, he wears his father's flannel shorts when he dives in to fix the water wheel. That was a hilarious scene in the book and should have been repeated in the episode.
3. In the Search, Claire again uses her healing skills - it's probably more entertaining to show the variety show that they do but it's also not so believable. I like that the episode does build the relationship between Claire and Murtaugh.
4. The last 2 episodes were very difficult to watch. I wish that they adapted the book - the wolf scene was cut out entirely, the scene with MacRannoch after the rescue was completely altered (it was really good in the book). Finally, more time should have been spent on Jamie and Claire's recovery (yes, it was for both). Claire had lots of character growth with her interactions with the priest at the abbey. There should have been more exorcising of Jamie's demons - I thought that was glossed over. It doesn't necessary have to be shown in entirety but have more emphasis in dialogue or an excerpt version. I really lament that Jamie's recovery and Jamie/Claire relationship was not extended. In the book, the snow scene with Jamie going out the window and walking outside in his nightshirt showed his character and stubbornness coming back. Jamie and Claire also start renewing their love for one another in a different way - since both went through the rough violence that Jamie experienced. I thought the final scene in the book was very sweet and tender - especially in how Jamie knew that Claire was pregnant.

It's hard to watch something that may not have matched your imagination when reading the book. But overall, I thought the episodes were very well done. If you haven't read the books, you would enjoy the story (not so much the images). If you have read the book, there were some lapses in Jamie going out of character and some favorite scenes that were deleted or altered.

The dvd collection is organized and it is nice they don't have a ton of trailers on the front. I wish it had fast play and the memory chip for pause and restart. I have no time to remember what episode I left off on. I would not recommend this for sensitive viewers. Lots of X rated scenes. It does follow the book sort of, but with extreme graphic violence and sex scenes this is not for the sensitive people. I find it highly odd that it is geared towards women and yet the style of video and editing is very manly oriented. Not much thought is given to unique transitions or beautiful lighting. It's very bare bones and tight budget for multiple shots. Editing is fine but it can drag in scenes. The hair and make up and costumes are spot on. I would hope that their future episodes don't waist time on recaps and showing multiple shared shots. They tend to reuse the same dramatic shot multiple times. It's better to have an implied thought or deeper meaning in an expression. Don't just show us exactly what the character went through.  I really can't stand recaps before each episode, I would cut those. They should put a skip chapter edit in the DVD so we can speed watch it. The chemistry between the characters is good. Jamie is charming and I can see that is why so many women watch it. But it could have been pushed further artistically. Acting wise great job to all the actors and they did a fabulous job with the limitations set on them.  Now, don't send me hate mail because I didn't love it. I said it was okay and men are more likely to enjoy it. It should be rated R or X for content and graphic shots. I am a little disappointed because I heard so many positive reviews and it seemed a let down. Story wise it is very well done. Lots of rising action and strong dialog. More time could be used for better dramatic compositions and perhaps some down time shots. A romantic film could use a better score of music.
Loved it...can't wait for more episodes!

I have never seen any book so well adapted to the screen. The programs make me laugh and cry, just as all eight books did. I have watched the entire first season seven times, and even though I know what is ahead it still affects me as profoundly as the first time. The actors are so genuine. To me they are even better than I had imagined them when I read the books. This is an epic series and magnificently done!

Excellent in every way! Visually rich and true to detail. Having been a rabid fan for many years, I was prepared for disappointment, but I have been more than pleasantly surprised by the quality of the acting,  the costumes, the historic detail, writing, directing, and everything else.

Not that I'm complaining... I was just surprised.  Maybe I've been watching too much Disney lately, and didn't realize that "grown up" tv had evolved so well.  Had I known, I would have given the kids an 8:00 bed time!  And I did tell my husband to feel free to take notes, in case inspiration hits.

There is one part of the series that I could not watch.. so I fast forwarded through that.  I do not want to say what it was, because I do not want to spoil the series.  But, since I read the book, and it disturbed me when I read it... I knew to hit the fast forward button on the remote.

No, seriously, this is not a show for young kids or even your teenagers... but I am loving the series... not only for the story line of a book I loved, but also because the script was well written and the filming, music, etc... are high quality.  It's a great series to watch with your hubbie snuggled in bed with the kids in another room fast asleep.

Where I live doesn't have Starz tv and I never heard of the Outlander books by Diana Gabaldon. It was sheer luck that I walked in a local dvds store and bought the Outlander's dvd for the first half Season One. After watching the first half season, my God, I was completely hooked by the intense but well-paced story plot, the high-quality and bold production; the characters in it were all well-acted by charming actors and actresses -- especially the leading actor and actress. It's just magical! I enjoy it so much that I consider that it's one of the BEST tv productions I have seen in the recent years. Since then I have been recommending this series to friends and I ordered the second half of the Season One through Amazon as well as the published books. I enjoyed both the tv series and the printed matters even though they tell the same story in slight different ways -- they both are spell-binding. Honestly, after reading the book, I vote that the tv production has done a very good job for condensing the time and events happened in the book -- it's really a good adaptation of Gabaldon's time-travel story. After all, movies/tv productions and books of words are two different media, we are lucky to be treated with such good writing by Diana Gabaldon and tv production from Starz tv.

Season One, Volume Two is just not very good.  It's a shame, really...the books were fantastic, the characters so well-cast, and Volume One really had a good feel for the characters and the events of the books.  Sure, it could not touch on all of the events in a 700+ page novel, but you understood why they skipped what they did and I felt that they chose key scenes.  But Volume Two seems to disregard the book in all but its broadest plot-wise sense.  The characters acted out of character:  Jamie just wouldn't have stomped into Lallybroch declaring himself Laird, Jenny was not predisposed to hate Claire, Murtagh would NOT have danced a jig on stage.  On Claire & Murtagh's search for Jamie in the book they went from village to village treating patients, because Claire was a well-known healer and Jamie would know that the English healer traveling the countryside was her.  I think if he heard of an English woman who sang weird songs for money he would have no inclination to look for her.  And above all, they stopped focusing on the growing love, friendship, and romance between Claire and Jamie...in the book, when Claire went back to the stones, you knew what a wrenching decision it was for her, and when she chose to stay you knew it was inevitable.  You also knew what a huge sacifice Jamie was making, and he was making it for her.  The show conveyed none of this...honestly, if I hadn't read the books I would have been puzzled as to why she would stay in a violent, primitive world when she had a loving husband back in her time.  The TV show just didn't make Claire & Jamie's love compelling enough.

Finally, in all honesty the shows are gettng boring.  I just finished dragging myself through The Search, and now I have the prison episode and the rape/torture episode left...and I am not sure I can work up enough interest to watch them.

Generally when a dvd is "not rated" it's because it could get a PG rating but the studio doesn't want to have the movie ignored by the General adult population.  But this time it's different, it is borderline X
Not Rated? 13 & up????  Should be rated R+, DIsturbing images, Graphic violence, Nudity throughout including full frontal & some of the violence is sexual in nature.  Seemed to find a reason to have a woman's breasts completely exposed in every episode.  All of these absolutely ruined the story for me.  I was intrigued with the story line and would have loved it and given it five stars if the gratutitous nudity and sexual assault was alluded to instead of so in my face.  Funnily enough, in the extras they said they didn't want to go sexual just to get an audience.  They spent more time filming that than following the plot. Everything is through the woman Claire's eyes  but this movie seemed to be filmed to attract a male audience.

Love this series.  Well made and reasonably true to the book.

Each episode draws the viewer further into this amazing journey into the past and is beautifully crafted with full tapestries of scenery, inside and out, and special effects details, which will make you remember this series as if you were there. The acting is superb at all levels, but the intense sexual content, quite graphic in some scenes, definitely make this a tale for mature audiences only. I have not read any of the books upon which this series is based, but my wife has. She thinks the adaptation follows the books quite closely, with due latitude given to the director and screen writers as they present a visual interpretation of the story. Definitely five-star!

The sex scenes are loving and passionate, as any new love relationship is. This is not a movie for children, but it is appropriate for mature adults. Other critical reviews on other subjects often seem overstated to me. There is obvious restraint present. This is a historical fiction movie and historically correct behavior is exhibited. The movie makers have used appropriate restraint in many areas without making the film a watered-down version of reality.

The stunning conclusion to Season 1. Impeccable costumes, sets, cinematography, writing and direction coupled with absolutely stellar and heartbreaking performances make this a must have. I have read all the books and could not be more pleased with this sensitive, yet compelling adaptation.

Where do I begin?  I bought volumes 1 & 2 Outlander series with my eyes open.  I read the first book and I read the reviews.  I like the story and the characters from the book, but I hated the ending enough that I lost interest in reading the rest of the series. I also read many reviews complaining that the Starz series was too violent and too graphic. I agree. This series is very violent and sexually graphic. The rape scenes and the nudity got old. (Then again, that is to be expected from series produced by the premium channels like Starz and HBO, etc.)

So why did I buy the first two seasons?  Call it curiosity. I still like the characters and the plot. I is also like the love story between Claire and Jamie. For the most part, I liked most of the episodes, especially episodes 2-6 from volume 2. (There are some good ones in volume 1 too.)  However, the last 2 episodes from volume 2 were so disturbing and brutal. The only way I could get through them was to fast forward through all the scenes with Jaimie and Black Jack.  What can I say, I don't enjoy watching people being raped and tortured.

Not sure that I have the interest or the stomach to continue watching.

I remember feeling shocked when I read all that detail too, but it does give insight into each person's character in how they dealt with such violation, and the extreme degree of base, vile, inhuman treatment coming from what appears the darkest of all seemingly soulless reprobate beings.

I was surprised to find out that my brother, with whom I share my Amazon content, had been waiting for volume 2, which speaks to how great this story is. I love how honest and true to the book this story is.  I know people will love the sex scenes, but they are more real and well acted than many I have seen, and they really do a great job of showing how the writer intended them to come off (Not as smut designed to fluff a story, but a way to paint the bond between two people in love).

The tension between Jack Randall, Claire, and Jamie is palpable and I was actually thinking they would dance around the exchanges between Jamie and Jack, especially the culminating ones.  I thought for sure they'd worry that too many people would be offended by male rape and that homophobia might prevent them from telling the true story, but they stayed true and and not only that, and not only did they NOT dance around the subject, but they went the full monty (har har) with it.

The casting is wonderful and  Diana Gabaldon's books come alive on the screen. The actors are true masters of their craft, beautiful period costumes, locations, cinematography is amazing. You will want to watch these DVD's over and over again, just as you re-read the books.  Can't wait for the next DVD to be released.

WOW, just WOW.  If you aren't a fan of Outlander, you are  missing something fantastic.  If you are, well no more needs to be said.  Based on the fabulous Diana Gabaldon's series of books, the show takes some slight deviations from the book.  Not to worry, however, because Ron Moore's commitment to the accuracy of the book's will not offend even the most passionate fan.  Even Diana approves.  Caitriona Balfe and Sam Heughan are stellar as Claire and Jamie along with all the supporting actors.  The scenery of Scotland alone is breathtaking.  This is truly a unique, one-of-a-kind production, from the story itself to the behind-the-scenes evolution of the show.  The last two episodes are hard to watch, but even a conservative like myself appreciated the enormous talent of Mr. Heughan, Ms. Balfe, and Tobias Menzies.
Love, love, love all of her books. This series does credit to Diana's writing!

I am torn because the cast and "feel" of the series are spot on and I enjoyed Volume One (although I did not enjoy watching Jamie being flogged.) I watched an interview before V-2 was released - the cast and crew were very matter of fact about how sexual content was integral to the book and they seemed to have a good feel for their audience.

I was puzzled why scenes should not follow the book more closely when there are 800 plus pages of material to choose from. Then the director decided to insert prolonged graphic (male/male) torture and rape scenes. I was shocked. These are events that do happen in the book but are revealed after the fact as part of the healing process- classic, if upsetting, "hurt, comfort" romance. The way the series is filmed it won't be enjoyable to re-watch. I will continue to enjoy ebook and audio versions.

I would like to see Season Two with theses distinctions: sex good/ torture bad (subtler sex is ok- do not have to see all body parts / the scars of torture are enough to deal with- do not wish to see them being inflicted.)

But I must say that I could not watch the toture and rape scenes that were brutal and went on for what seems like hours. I kept fast forwarding to get out of it which is not as easy when you are live streaming it as if it was on a dvd. My husband who watched with me, and has not read the books, said, "Well, was all of this in the books?" I said, "yes, but at least then you could skim it and skip over the parts and you did not have all the visuals and noises and great acting right in your face." I really disagree with the choice here by the directors and author to so strongly dwell on this part of the book. After 15 minutes, I felt we totally got the horror and the brutality and understood how these acts shaped many other relationships and decisions that went on in the book, and books to follow. But enough was enough.

Good mixture of historic facts, historic fiction and science fiction. One can only hope that the author, TV writer, director and producer have not packed everything exciting into the first season...and the subsequent ones will just drag themselves along and fizzle out. I believe a lot will largely depend on the screenwriter, because  if you have actually read all of Diana Gabaldon's  7 or 8 books of the 'outlander series you will have noted that while they are all more than 700 pages, with the exception of the first one, the action often drags along, events sometimes seem unconnected and the author seemed to have gotten lost in trivial stuff instead of continuing with the actual "meat" of the story. The story also jumps around quite bit, some things simply remain unexplained, and the personalities which Ms. Gabaldon has attached to some of her later characters do not always seem to be the best choice. All in all, in the following books Jaimie and Claire are being robbed of a good portion of excitement that seemed to follow them throughout the first book and the first season. So let's see whether the coning tv seasons will be better and less confusing and at times tedious than the actual books

There  is a grittiness to this series that is unusual in television, not just because there is violence but because it's a very personal kind of violence and shown with a stark lack of sentimentality. That quality is very true to the books, although it makes certain scenes almost unwatchable (for me). The harshness of life in that era provides a counterpoint to the fantastical premise of time travel, though, being so grounded in the dark realities of human nature and of the earth itself. They have done an incredible job of bringing the book to life!

Where do I start? I am thoroughly impressed with how real and colorful the dialogue is for this show. I was completely drawn in and really identify with the characters as people (real people not Hollywood contrivances). I loved the books when I read them years ago, but I have fallen hard for the storyline as it's being told here. The person that wrote the screenplay for this needs to be held up as an example of writing about what real human interaction is all about (the complexity, the interplay of light and dark within ourselves, the tactile sensation of living and not just existing, loving someone so desperately that you'll do anything for that person ). Claire's character astounds me with the delicate balance of strength and vulnerability.  It's extremely hard to express in words, what has so eloquently and realistically been depicted on screen. I pray that this series has a few more seasons to run. My creative side (with regards to television) finally has something to yearn for.

When I first heard about this TV series, I was very excited. Having a doctorate in history, I have a deep appreciation for historical fiction that actually is well written and researched by the author. My particular area of study is Celtic history, and I have spent much time in Scotland and Ireland. All of that to say when I heard about Gabaldon's series that blended two of my favorite areas of history (WWII & Eighteenth Century Scotland) I was stoked. She carries high praise for a writer that seems to have a great grasp of highland clan life, language, and culture......BUT, this TV series is way over the top! What could have been such a good series is nothing less that sheer pornography. Both "Outlander Seasons" were in the garbage can last week, hopefully at the bottom of landfill by now. Is it really necessary for there to be endless sex, nudity, rape, and perversion scenes for you to be entertained?? Such garbage should not be necessary for good art. There are many other creative ways to be true to reality without turning sex into a spectators sport. Artistic integrity is not what puts sexual perversion on the screen. Underneath is an out of control sexual appetite that this industry plays into in hopes their ratings will go up! It is not good art that puts nudity on the movie screen, its prurience. For the masses that took pleasure in viewing such a series, it is an indicator of how serious your depravity is, for you no longer are satisfied to think on what is honorable. DON'T justify sick perverted things in the name of entertainment and amusement. Ask anyone who has been sexually abused if they would enjoying watching such a TV show such as this. Or a father if he would be happy for his daughter or son to play in such a acting role. Human dignity and beauty should not be sold so cheaply. So, agreeing with some others, you have to be a very sadistic person to conceive writing such a script or to enjoying watching this on the screen. In short...this series is trash, don't buy it.

-Filleann an feall ar an bhfeallaire

The only complaint I have is it wasn't accurate to the book, a lot of the movie was not in the book, which is disappointing. But I still love the acting, very well performed.

I love this show Sam & Caitriona are amazing Wentworth Prison and To Ransom A Man's Soul just left me gutted breathtaking performance from Sam. I can't wait for the new season to begin on STAR.  I pre ordered and no money was taken out of my account until it was released

I'm an Outlander junkie but don't get Starz, so owning the series on DVD is a necessity for me.

I'm an Outlander reader and I think this serial does the books justice and are extremely well acted and directed. I couldn't be better pleased. Every scene is essential to the story and every character is fascinating. I just hate that we'll have to wait between productions to get the whole series completed. A must for Scottish history buffs and romance lovers. Tension, intrigue, raw, real, and sweepingly adventurous.

Love everything about this story. Diana Gabaldon is an amazing writer. Her research is incredible. I've read all her Claire and Jamie books and can't stop wanting more. The mini series has been faithful to the story and I hope the producers continue the series.

My second favorite tv series. The Walking Dead is #1.  Love the actors in their roles, especially Sam Heughan as Jamie Frasier.  But....the final episode with Jamie being horribly tortured sexually by Jack Randall was just way over the top!  I had to fast forward to the end.  Yes, it was somewhat in keeping with the book version....but the book was written with a bit more discretion. We don't have to see it all to know it happened. A person can only stomach so much torture, sexual molestation and rape from one man to another man. Awful to watch....well I couldn't very long!  I hope Season 2 will be less gratuitous.
I loved the series and now the DVD.
This is my absolute favorite show. I was so excited when my order finally came in.

There is just no way that books of such volume can be portrayed correctly on the screen, they highlighted the sex and grave details missing much of the story, and to top that off? Eight episodes and you have to wait months for more? Ridicules! I paid $14 a month for Starz in order to watch this ONE show $168 a year, the channel has nothing else I wanted to see; movies I've already seen. I could have bought the stupid DVD for $22 at Wallyworld!! Which is what I will do to see the rest...if there is a "rest" to see. I think it was well done, but still maintain you cannot get the whole story from this...the books are better, and even those need major editing of all her "going nowhere" parts due to the way she writes.

The fabulous Outlander story as seen through male eyes.  Claire, our heroine,  and other beloved female characters lurch from one contrived situation involving gratuitous female nudity to the next, while male characters remain modest and retain their dignity.  Very disappointing.  Leaves you wondering what BBC could have done with this outstanding saga.  Save your money!  Wish I could un-see it.

I love the casting and acting in this series. The scenery is just beautiful. Season 1 Volume 1 was amazing and passionate, and I binge watched it because I had to know what happened next. Everything was there to make me an addict for the life of the series. However, in this volume, I found myself looking away in embarrassment during the pornographic sex scenes and had to fast forward the torture scenes in the final episode of Volume 2. The story is much more captivating and beautiful without all of this. The actors portray feeling so well that such graphic scenes aren't necessary. I hope they go back to the fine storytelling of the first volume from now on.

I was completely captivated by season 1, volume 1, so much so that I purchased and read the first 4volumes, approximately 1,000 pages each.  Needless to say, I counted the days until the release of volume 2.  I had the set as my first two choices with Netflix and on the first day of release purchased the DVD knowing I would want it as part of
my all things Outlander. Wise choice on my part-- I couldn't wait to return my purchase!  Much of this volume 2, season 1 should have ended up on the editing floor.  Ms. Gabaldon had no trouble in expressing the horror depicted in words.  This could and should have been done better without subjecting your fans to unforgettable images disguised as "entertainment".  Have new editing room/screenwriters been employed?  To sink to your level for a moment, disc one could be entitled "Nipples" and disc 2  "The Gut Wrenching Depravity of Man", all disguised as "entertainment".

Where is the beautiful scene at the monastery?  In future episodes, please do not subject your fans to such graphic brutality visually -- there has to be a better way!

On yet another thought please include the same "extras" on both regular DVD's as are on Blu ray.  I will now always view through Netflix before buying.  I have watched the first season, volume 1 no less than 9 times so far, and NEVER intend to watch volume 2 again.  Please do better, the books are marvelous and can be more than enough!
my favorite book and tv show
GREAT THANKS A+++++++

I have read all of the Outlander books, so I was aware that Diana Gabaldon likes to include sexuality, but I find the overly graphic sex scenes (I don't see how they are any different from pornography) and frankly gratuitous nudity ruins a perfectly good story line.  There must be a market for this or the producers wouldn't do it, but isn't anyone else insulted that we are all considered so low-minded and base?

Loved Season One - Volume One, but this volume is just over the top with nudity and sex, including the rape of Jamie by the evil captain in prison, which goes on and on in graphic detail through multiple shows ....  Honestly, it sucked .... and, yes, there's some of that in there as well ...  Lots of male and female sex as well, full-frontal nudity and so on. ..... I'm not a prude, but the sex in this set of shows did not add to the story - rather, it detracted from it ....  .. Then Jamie went from seriously injured with PTSD to oh-I'm-fine in just 2-3 scenes and they sailed happily off to France ....  That's just not going to happen - and neither is the miracle-healer surgery with his ruined hand ...  Let me know when you people get done with your sex and magic-healer stuff and start providing good evening entertainment again ....
Awesome! Fabulous!

I have read all the Outlander books and thoroughly enjoyed them. I watched volume 1 and liked about 80% of it.  I guess translating a book to the screen is not easy.  That said, I was disappointed in the portrayal of Outlander. Follow the book - take the dialogue from it (which they did somewhat). The acting by the actors is excellent but I just didn't feel J & C had much of a connection as I viewed each episode especially the last 4.  I found some of the scenes tedious and boring.  The torture scene between Jamie and Black Jack was not necessary to go on as long as it did.  Give it 5 minutes to get the point across and move on. Why spend so much time on these horrible acts and less on the healing aspect. Maybe the writers think the public would prefer torture to healing? Which it seems they were right after reading so many positive reviews. I doubt I will buy Season 2 (I don't get Starz) but watching this DVD has wet my appetite to return to the books and read them again.

I love the show but the episodes stream poorly on Roku.  It's so frustrating.  It must have stopped to load a dozen times.  So this is a review for the instant video, not the show.  I'm happy to throw down $2 an episode for this kind of show, but it really sucks when it takes twice as long as it should to watch, and there's no way to fix it.  It's like repeated commercial breaks right in the middle of a scene.  Argh!  I bought the first half of the season as a package in HD and that streamed fine.  But the second half, regular version (cheapest to pay per episode of non-HD) has streamed badly for the first two episodes.  It's not our internet connection.  We checked that, and other streaming programs on Roku are working fine.

What a bummer that after such a wonderful, engrossing, magnificent first volume for the season, they had to stumble so hard with this second half. I understand that the rape and torture happened in the book. I am not terribly squeamish (I have sat through GoT and Spartacus without a blink) and I am not the least bit homophobic, but I do think there is a limit. Watching an ENTIRE episode full of rape and torture was too much. It didn't have to be so graphic. I was willing to pay whatever the silly prices were to buy both of these "collector's editions" and ended up disappointed in the last portion of the second volume. I wish they had just insinuated a bit more or maybe, at the very least, dedicated a bit more to the healing that occurs in the book. It isn't just dark and dreary sodomy! Three stars for you, you silly shock value addicted wankers. :)

I LOVE OUTLANDER!!!  I have been a fan of the books and cannot wait for the next book to come out, but to see the book on screen makes it all the better!!  I have seen reviews talking about the sex and rape scenes and how it offends them, and to those of you who are easily offended and don't like to watch the depths of human emotion and despair then this show is not for you.  But to those of you who like to watch, and read for that matter, shows that allow you to witness the human portrayal of both happiness and despair then you will be elated with this series!!  In reality the good guy does not always win, and to witness the hero and heroine struggle with the obstacles, that have been thrown in their way and still come out fighting is amazing to watch!!

From the casting, costumes, and location Starz nailed this one on the head. I hope this series is around for years to come!!!

"After having read all the books and bulges, I knew what was coming. You can always put a book down if it becomes disturbing. And the same with this series. I watched the last episodes in bits and pieces, as I could tolerate them. I actually finally was able to watch the last two episodes in entirety yesterday. And as disgusting the scenes are (what happened, not the depictions), you have to admit that the acting of both the BJR and Jamie characters is amazing!"

So, thank you, Roger & Company and as always, to Diana.  I'll pretend to be on a first name basis with Herself-she has been an important part of my life for 20+ years.  And I won't ask her when #9 is coming out!

I had been looking forward to seeing Outlander come to life for a long time.  Unfortunately, it still hasn't.  While there are some talented cast members (not naming names either way, nothing good to come of that), most of the characters have been written so as to be unrecognizable, and in particular, I've found very little to like about the main characters as they've been written for the show.  The plot has been mangled, taking out really great scenes in favor of new ones that are just painfully bad (the "Boogie Woogie" scenes have to take the cake on that), and I'm a little embarrassed to have been excitedly recommending the show before it started, thinking it would be of GoT quality.  Volume One of this season is okay, though not great; in this half, I found myself either multitasking while watching, or just rolling my eyes

The second Volume,as I understand it, is not available until 9/29/15. The first volume impresses one particularly with Claire and Jamie; the chemistry is amazing and an historical drama is fascinating. I majored in history in college and 18th century Europe is my favorite historical period. Women have no power whatsoever,yet Outlander doesn't ruin the story based on historical accuracy. Claire, coming from the 20th century is a phenomonon in 18th century Scotland and in the upcoming second volume which apparently takes place in 18th century Paris. The costumes are apparently amazing.

I 'love' a believable romance and through volume 1,Claire has NOT,yet given up on an attempted and hopeful return to 20th century Britain,following WW2. I have often been 'peeved', at times with the insistence that the primary characters are beautiful or extraordinarily handsome but this formula works especially well with Outlander. For the historians among us; John Prebble's books and Sir Walter Scott's novels have always made this period a romantic one. Knowing that Culloden is 2 years away brings a focus to the series which defines great historical fiction. I recommend this series for all who treasure a good love story and those who want to learn about European history near our American Revolution!

I agree with others that the price for the two volumes is very high for the total number of episodes.  I was also disappointed with the second half of the series, especially the last two episodes.  While the acting was superb, there was way too much time and focus on the graphic and disturbing elements, and way too little on the very moving and joyful elements that were in the book.  For example, the horrible rape could have been alluded to in a few scenes of a few seconds each, instead of devoting many very long and horrid minutes to it, which would have allowed time for us to see Jamie's healing, and the book's lovely was of announcing her pregnancy (which in the TV series was wooden and a huge let down).  If I had not read the books to know what was coming, I would not even want to watch the next season.

Without a doubt this is the best show on television, bar none.  The quality & production from the tiniest details to the most magnificent are first rate from start to finish.  It's the kind of show you can't watch just once.  Each viewing releases more and more of the magic, romance and incredible story for the viewer to soak into.  Reading Diana's books only adds to the layered effects as well as the story lines via Ron Moore's guidance. His interpretation for the series leaves one breath-taken with the scenery, music and overall impact of the amazing romance.  I've found watching episodes either in order or out of order again and again much like reading poetry.  The impressions one takes away from watching true beauty in its best illustration - even when the plots thicken into horror - is something you will never forget.  I am in awe with Diana's vast imagination and Ron's depth of talent to turn these sublime stories into sheer classics of the very best kind. How can one argue with perfection much less quibble with its cost?
A one-word review: AWESOME!!!!

For anyone who has not read the books prior to watching the series - watch out!  There is a horribly graphic and extensive "scene" in the book and it sounds like the series stuck pretty close to the book.  I have read the series many times, and intentionally skip over this part.  To some extent, I think one needs to get the idea of what happened to Jaime in order to understand how difficult his recovery is and all the things he goes through later as he grows and heals etc.  Rest assured, although sex is a common recurring event throughout the series.  This is the worst.  And unless they depart from the book (I doubt it) I think it can be safely said that all can go back to watching the rest of the series without fear of this same level of - well, I'm not sure what to call it - but, as far as I remember, the worst is over and we can get back to the story which is so wonderful without fear of any similar scenes taking us by surprise.  If you haven't watched the series yet (I haven't) it sounds from other reviews that this graphic scene is the last of the season?  Definitely good to know so that one can skip it if so inclined.

I know what you're thinking - 90 something dollars for one season of a TV show?! Expensive yes but when I think of how many times I'm going to rewatch it's worth it. The casting is perfect (Sam Heughan as Jamie Fraser is everything) and Vol. 2 seems to be taking enough creative licence to keep fans guessing, particularly the scenes with Laoghaire. An historical romance set in beautiful Scotland - You won't be disappointed!

This series is THE BEST and I can't stop watching it over and over! The book is spot on within this series and I greatly appreciate it. My husband totally loved this series as well so never should it be said it's a ladies love!

I was utterly enchanted with the first eight episodes BUT I do not watch porn, not rape porn and certainly not torture porn.  The creeps who produce  that sort of thing can keep it.  I really wish I could send the first half of the season back now.  I feel really ripped off.

Such a disappointment after the first half of this season. The final episode was disturbingly graphic and it seemed as though there was not enough time dedicated to Claire and Jamie's reunion following so much darkness and tragedy.

Season 1 - Volume Two of Outlander is gritty, realistic, sometimes hard to watch, and I found it completely impossible to tear myself away from it. Yes, there is nudity, but the nudity is nothing more than present in the story, and I am a typical American prude and did not find it offensive. The last two episodes were sometimes hard to watch as they courageously tackled the issues of torture and rape in a disturbingly realistic manner. These things are occurring daily today in war and terror torn parts of the world and closing our eyes to it does not make it go away. Outlander approaches these things from the correct perspective of truth, showing them to be the desire of evil people to dominate and control, nothing to do with sex. The psychological effects are explored in depth, and yes it hard to watch Jamie and Claire struggle through these two episodes, coming to terms with the aftermath of evil. If the end of this season does not tear your heart out, you may not have one, but it is an incredible testament to the power of love. The closing scene of the final episode, To Ransom A Man's Soul, left my eyes filled with tears of joy and hope for these wonderful characters for Season Two.

From a technical standpoint, the history and geographical beauty of Scotland is nothing less than another character that does not appear in the list of credits. The acting is truly the best I have ever seen. It was intensely done, sometimes funny, sometimes painful, I could see nothing of the actors in the characters. The characters were simply their own beings, as if they were truly living individuals. Always, adding to the beauty of Scotland, the joy of love, the intensity of a whole range of emotions, is the amazing music of Bear McCreary, surely one of the most talented people in the industry. Outlander is the best thing I have ever watched and I am looking forward to Season Two more than I can say.

I watched  Volume One and afterwards immediately ordered Volume Two.  Outlander is truly a magnificent adventure.  The actors are superb and visuals are extraordinary!  I just can't wait till Vol. 2 is available.  The storyline is excellent and the action intense.  Everything flows exceptionally.  If you're into this type of historical fiction don't hesitate to spend the money.  You won't regret it.

Season one volume one is very true to the original story. The scenery is breathtaking, and they put more than a little effort into the costumes.  There are certain adult situations that are probably not suitable for younger viewers.  I thought it was a bit pricey, and I would recommend watching an episode or two before you decide to invest in this.

As to the cost for the entire 16 episodes...for a Prime member the total would come to $70 plus change.  16 episodes at about $5 per episode.  A two-hour movie on CD is more than $10.  The price for the first season of Outlander is not at all outrageous.

The absolute best show on TV!!!!!  I had never read the books until I found Outlander on the Starz Channel.  I binge watched most of the first half of the season in one night and finished the last three episodes of the first half the next morning.  I very rarely, if ever, binge watch anything.  This show grabbed on to me and wouldn't let go from the first show.  When I found out it was a book adaptation, I ordered all eight books and started reading and was almost finished before the second half of the season started (two months later).  I am not one of those Book Snobs who bad mouth this series because it is not word for word/scene for scene exactly like the book.  There are just some things that will not work on TV.  Like the author of the books has said probably more than once, put the book down and enjoy the show for what it is - an adaptation.  And yes, they deal with some hard issues in both the books and the TV adaptation.  They don't sugar coat the hard life that was the 1700's.  You want fairy tale Cinderella, then buy/watch Cinderella.  If you want to experience something close to what it must have been like in the 1700's (for women especially), then watch this series.  Yes, there are some rough moments (especially episodes 115 and 116), but the acting in those last two episodes is so stellar that IMHO, you are missing out on some Emmy caliber performances if you don't watch them.  And trust me, it goes into much more detail in the books than they could ever do on TV.
LOVE, LOVE, LOVE IT! I CAN HARDLY WAIT FOR THE NEXT SEASON!

Not being able to get the Starz Network, I only learned bits and drips about this tv series from the media praising the caliber of this production.  Finding them on Facebook to learn more, while seeing all the positive comments, I was drawn to purchase the 1st in book series by Diana Galabon.  She's one master story teller and captured my attention page by page, whereby you want to keep reading and reading.  Hence, I purchased Season One without even knowing if all the buzz was worthy.  Outlander is solid to sink your teeth into, and filmed expertly with lots of attention to detail. Having visited Scotland this year, I can see why this country has appeal as a cinematic one - it is gorgeous.  I haven't come across any other historical take on a country, it's inhabitants, it's romance and strife that has been as enthralling as Outlander.  Credit goes to R. Moore as director, and Diana for writing an excellent series of books. Sam and Caitriona are excellent actors and bring this show to life.  Am not impervious to the violence and sex, which is treated realistically and tastefully.  Being a Scot by family lineage I now appreciate learning about the Jacobites and am drawn into learning even more. Keep the series going, it's far better than Game of Thrones for all the right reasons.

Wonderful series.  I throughly enjoyed it, but why, oh why, did they have to get so graphic about Jamie.  Yes, it was "in the book", but this kind of graphic display was beyond horrible.  We purchased the first half of the season, but we are not going to purchase this half.  The last two episodes go into god-awful gory detail, and while some explanation of what happened to Jamie is necessary, it does not have to go into horrific mode.  Porn I can deal with, but this was not porn, it was horror.  If I want to see a movie about human torture, go see Saw I, II and III (no, I did not watch those either).  Perhaps some people get off on this kind of stuff, but my wife and I were completely horrified.  We watched hoping it would get better, but it just kept going deeper and darker.

The Screen Writer, the Director and Producer, are, in my opinion, sick.  Keep going down this road, for you have, at least, lost this audience.
This price is upsetting and off-putting, and I can't help wondering how much of an increase there will be for every 8 episodes to come.

I have finished volume I and can't wait for the release of vol 2!! The story holds very true to the books, which I appreciate.  I'm so happy there is finally an epic tale like this for women--romance and love instead of the usual sex and lewd behavior... Not that I dislike Game of Thrones, but this is more my style.

Yeah. I saw lots of reviews posted elsewhere. This one and the ones on Sansa Stark's rape seem to be major news in the TV world. But here I'll stick with Outlander. I liked the overall take on the TV series initially. I loved the gorgeously shot setting; the detail that was put into the historical dress for the time period; the Gaelic interspersed with the English drew me in further to the physicality of the place and time. This was all well done. The casting was also very well done. But there is a limit, and even a great TV series that hits all of the right notes, will stumble occasionally.

I was loving the affection and the slowly evolving relationship between Jamie and Claire, which caused me to tune in each week. But that ended a couple episodes back. I found Jamie withdrawing from Claire, or beginning to distance himself from her during "The Watch" episode. In that episode, Claire kisses Jamie goodbye, and Jamie doesn't even react to the kiss. Mood killer. And since that episode, the rest of the closeness of Jamie and Claire has been "dying/languishing." For me, something has been "off" between them since that episode, and has stayed that way.

Anyway, this last episode was underwhelming, too. I rate it a "8" not because Sam Heughan and Tobias Menzies didn't "step it up" with their acting. No, they most certainly did step it up with their acting, and the result was mind-numbing and was cringe-worthy. But the rest of this episode besides the flashbacks was TOTALLY NOT on the same level. The result is a disjointed ending.

I read the book, sure, and for most of the TV series, they did adhere quite well to the book. I'm not saying DG was phenomenal in writing the first book, but I do think Ron Moore, the director, took a nosedive with this last episode of the show, when he proceeded to not give equal gravity to the healing scenes between Claire and Jamie in the monastery, and only provided the rape/torture scenes between BJR and Jamie.

Claire's few scenes with Jamie in this episode were wooden. Heughan stayed on target with the theme from the book, where Jamie succumbs to the mental torture he has endured at BJR hands. Claire was rather dissociated from Jamie, and during her early signs of pregnancy, she kept fainting all during this episode.  There were very little "scenes" of healing going on for Jamie. Ron Moore and the company producers basically glossed over all of the "healing scenes" provided in he book in order to make the episode "grittier" and all about the rape of Jamie.

 Graphic sex scenes between lovers are the norm these days. It's not everyone's cup of tea. That's granted.  But graphic rape scenes shown on TV, with practically nothing else going on for the entire episode... is purely BAD SCREENWRITING.  Sure, the rape of Jamie is understood in the book, and could have been reflected in small glimpses of flashback.  But what happened is that an entire 15-35 minutes of a 1 hour episode was devoted to showing the rape in all of its grisly detail.  Honestly, that's not an episode of TV.  That's torture porn, or akin to watching footage of terrorists doing beheadings on screen for an hour. ( If that's what you do for entertainment...then, okay).  And that's why the second half of season one, I think, is worse than the first half.  Jamie and Claire's relationship is supposed to change because of the rape, yes, but their relationship should not be hitting the skids before the rape even happens.  Also,  using a whole episode to show rape is not telling a story.  It's making the rest of the "story's plot" come to a screeching halt.

Save yourself some of the misery of trying to watch the finale of this season. Just go read the book's slightly detached ( but really horrific on its own) version, instead. The book version will make you feel bad, but it will not make you feel like you had just stuck your head in the toilet for an hour, with images you still can't erase from your mind.

I have nothing but good things to say about this show and about the novels.  I began devouring these books a little while ago and am currently on the third one. I get why people are upset about the male rape scene. It upset me when I read it but it was supposed to. It is a key element of the story that is essential to the growth and relationship between Claire and Jamie.  They were never NOT going to show it, and it's Starz, not Lifetime, so for those of us who are upset at how graphic it was, it was sort of to be expected. Those of us who read the books were well prepared for that scene and the overwhelming reaction from book readers was that these scenes were extremely well done and captured the horror and heartbreak that we all felt while reading Jamie's account of what happened to him in prison. You're just going to have to be okay with this going in, and if you're not then I would highly recommend finding another show.  This story is not for everyone, but if you can bear through the rape scene (which is the worst moment in the novels I've read so far) you will be greatly rewarded with Claire and Jamie's story, which is a story about the real, nitty-gritty type of love that exists beyond moments when everything is going smoothly and wonderfully.  Most Hollywood romances don't take us past the courtship period, and so rarely do we see what happens to the lovers after they are already married and taking on life's ups and downs together.  I have been consistently inspired by Gabaldon's writing and highly encouraged people to read her work, even if they do not make it past season one of the show.

I have read all 8 books and of course am waiting  for 9. I was surprised with Season One because not knowing the actors etc. .It was a pleasure to finally see Outlander on TV .The series was excellent. It followed Diana's books nearly to a tee.. Acting was  excellent . Everything about it was so good I have reread the books and watched Season one as often as I was able too. Season  Two was even better. I know people are not happy to see the torture and rape but it was in the book and it tells the  life story of  Jamie and Claire .What life's hardships they endured . We see it in our lives today the same hardships. We can actually feel their pain and happiness. When we can do that either reading the books or seeing on screen that is excellent work all around.. Could we possibly give it 6 stars.

$70 is an outrageous amount to pay for one season, $35 per volume!!! This series could possibly go on for 8-10 seasons if it encompasses the total of the 8 one thousand page books written. How expensive would that be to own the full series!! Ridiculous!!!!! Will not pay it!!!!

This review contains a spoiler alert!

Finally made it through to the Season 2 finale and I am absolutely finished with this series! The graphic rape and torture scenes overshadow any romance or plot it had going for it, and seem mostly gratuitous. I had hopes when I started watching as Ronald Moore is involved, but it is just like all the other Starz series: beautifully filmed with decent acting, but riddled with silly writing and loaded with sex and violence. I watch a lot of cable series, so porn doesn't bother me - the really excessive violence on Starz does. I almost quit watching after season 1 as that season ended naturally with the heroine about to be raped - she is saved in the nick of time but not before her bare butt and bosom are well displayed for the audience. Season 2 was far more degrading and humiliating for men and women. It was a real chore to watch. There was one moment when we discover another character traveled there from 1969 (a clue would be when she started using the F word - not something even Claire's generation tossed out liberally). I watched the rest of the season to learn more about that, but it was never mentioned again. They mostly focused on prison scenes, rapes scenes and more rape scenes. Oh yes and a silly witchcraft trial straight out of the 1960's soap opera Dark Shadows. You've been warned!

Might be interesting to fans of the books. As for me, I am through watching and not likely to read one of the books now in case they are even half as silly and violent as this show.

I watched the 1st 8 episodes with a lot of reserve.  I loved the books and feared I would be disappointed in the screen version.  My imagination is vivid and  I loved what I pictured when I listened to/ read the books.
Not to worry, the story lines are very close, the producers and camera work, is amazing!  I just had to adjust to the difference in appearance of the prime actors/ actresses.  I will continue to order these and watch them over and over!  Thank You to everyone's hard efforts!

What a great show. The acting, the costumes, the scenery...who cares if they split it into 2 DVDs it's still great artistry and drama! Isn't that what entertainment is about? No reason to give it a low rating as we are rating the show not DVD production.
One of the best series that has yet to hit STARZ.  I do hope they will show all of the story of Jamie and Clair.

I have been waiting since the 90's for this story to hit the screen. I am not disappointed. This DVD has been watched over and over again. I plan on purchasing the second half as soon as it hits the market.
This series are a wonderful version from the books. I have them in paper and electronic. I've watched the series on Starz and love it. I have to have the DVD as well!

Outlander has done a terrific job of bringing faces and vitality to the book's characters.  I love the episodes.m I have watched it several times and do not get tired of them ever.  I an hardly wait for the last half of the 1st season.
i loved the books and the folks that put this production together found the right people to play the parts and this series did the books justice!

I love Outlander and Diana Gabaldon.  Big Fan of the show and read all of the book twice... the last two episode's of the show was a bit to much for me and my boyfriend.  It was a disservice to the show and the books.. I can no longer go around telling friends, family and people in line at the store  about Outlander because of it.  Diana had more class about leaving that to the mind and understand that we didn't need it to be shoved into our face.  So for season one Volume one.  5 stars Volume two... all great... but for the butt. NOW FOR AMAZON what the hell .... I order this back in April and the show is over.  Get on it already. I am sure you have had a lot of people cancel their order.  If you would have sent it out after the last episode, I believe you would have kept some fans and money... the last thing I think you need. So sorry one star. Outlanders #1 fan.  Yet I want the show to make it so ....

I truly loved season 1 - vol  1... Just concerned on how long it will be for season 1 vol 2 comes out  ?
( why it wasn't made as season 1 season 2 & etc.)  Gets to confusing when you go seson1 -  vol. 1  Season 1-  vol. 2
I was captivated with the whole season 1 - vol 1  wanted more.. Didn't want it to end..

Please keep them coming ...
Thank you Diana Gabaldon is a wonderful writer.

Sincerely,
Ellen Wuest

I read the books many years ago and enjoyed them .  I watched Season 1 Volume 1 on Starz and enjoyed the superb treatment of the story and the romance.  I also commend the very talented actors.  That said,  I echo reviewer "M&M" regarding the gratuitously graphic sex.  It detracts from the story and the romance of the story.  No prude I, but in my considered opinion, it would have been far superior treatment of the love story had the producers/writers left the love-making to the imagination.  Think Rhett carrying Scarlet up that enormous staircase in Gone with the Wind.  Or Jean-Baptiste's donned clothes and sword in front of the fireplace in the film Desiree, with the couple's voices off-camera.  I cancelled Starz and won't be buying or watching Volume Two.

I have already written one review, but feel compelled to write another.  Gave it 3 stars the first time and now lowered to 2. I am sure my review will be very unpopular.  I gave it two stars because the choice of characters is excellent, but...I am very disappointed and offended that they chose to have so much nudity and bloody gore.  I know Diana Gabaldon took liberties with this in her books, but it was not necessary to include it on the screen.  They shout freedom of speech, but what about good taste.  Before anyone says something about my comment and what they perceive as my lack of sexuality, excuse me, but I definitely don't have problems in that area.  I just don't want people lined up at my bedroom door and I don't want to be lined up at theirs.  That is a special part of life that is for two people that love each other.  It is no wonder that our youth think it is OK to have sex in a room full of people when we let them watch this and praise and laugh at the shows.  I was told by Timewarner when I subscribed for Starz that it was more family oriented than the other movie channels.  Wow, they were so wrong and Starz will be cancelled very soon.  It is a shame that a wonderful Scottish love story is turned into an R, or is that X, rated show for TV with sex as the main theme.  Life is so much more and this was shown in many scenes and well played by the characters, but then the focus turned to how many different ways and how often the sex act can be displayed.  I heard some of the stars speak of wearing modesty patches when filming.  Do they actually think that saves their modesty?  The recent episode where Jack Randall couldn't "perform" with full frontal view was disgusting.  I kept hoping it would get better, but with this show, my TV was turned off.  Too many parents let their young children watch shows of this kind and their innocence is taken away.  We all know of the horrors of a battlefield and that era of Scottish history is no different, but it doesn't need to be portrayed in such vivid detail.  Again, I am disappointed, but I am sure the majority really don't care.
Outlander is a wonderful series. I fell in love with the characters and the clothing is so accurate to the period. That alone is impressive. It inspired me to read the books.
why so much nudity? starting to have to watch older shows so I don't get the surprise fully nakedness and random unwarned sexual details, come on guys leave something for the imagination.

The storyline certainly held my interest and the scenery was beautiful.  I am quite annoyed, however, that I had to purchase Season 1 in two parts: each at $19.99.  Thats almost $40!!  Im interested in seeing the following seasons but won't at that price.  I think you are getting a little greedy.
I was a fan of season one but season 2 seemed like it was drug out in order to fill time and the story line was lacking.

I loved it, but I think there is way too much gratuitous sex. Yeah, they have a lot of sex, we get it. They could have put a lot more into the show if they cut out some of the sex. Honestly, Catriona demeans herself. It would be better to leave a bit to the imagination. Far sexier that way.

Absolutely amazing! I have been told about this series for years, but only recently got around to reading the books and watching the STARZ dramatization. I found the two main characters as portrayed by Caitriona Balfe and Sam Heughan true to the books in every way. As a fan of Celtic history, and Scottish lore in particular, I found the settings, costumes, and dialects beyond satisfying. So far, I have read Book One and
watched Season One with avid obsession. I've cried uncontrollably in parts, sometimes for joy, sometimes for grief. The story definitely evokes strong emotions, which is part of its allure. Once drawn into the drama, it is impossible to forget or to set aside. It becomes an obsession almost immediately.
Initially I didn't realize that Season 1 was split into two volumes but this completes your Season 1 collection. It's seriously amazing. Get it!
Loved the series
A great finishing to a phenomenal first season. Although my husband doesn't enjoy the show I LOVE it and cannot get enough of it. From romance to action it covers everything a woman might need!
Love this series!  Great price!
